title: Dual Y Axis Homing Issue
body:
Hi,
I have a dual Y axis system running. Movement is working fine. However, as soon as I try to do homing only one Y axis is moving. The other seems not to move which quickly results in a jammed-up gantry.

What am I doing wrong? What am I missing? As said, normal movement works perfectly.

Regards,
Juergen

title: Grbl not working properly on two-axis system (was TB6600 drivers not working with grbl).
body:
What's the secret to getting grbl to signal TB6600 stepper drivers properly? I can drive them just fine using my own arduino program, but grbl seems not to know how. I've played with every setting I can think of (but I have not modified the config.h settings). Nothing works. When I run a G command the motors lock and hum, but no motion occurs.

I'm using the 1.1h release of gnea/grbl.

title: Problem with feedrates on a Foam cutter. GRBL limitation?
body:
Hi,

I built a Foam cutting machine running GRBL. I started generating my Gcode files with Inkscape+Gcode tools extension.

My machine is capable of jogging at 2000mm/min but during a cut the maximum speed **at all times** should not exceed 400mm/min.  As you may know, this is all due to the fact that foam cutters are not like milling machines where the bit is in the air while travelling from a point to another, here the cutting element is always in contact with the material.

On one hand, If I leave $110&$111 at 2000mm/min when I start a Gcode, the wire will literally crash into the material with the first G00 rapid move until the cut reaches the first actual cut point and the proper feedrate is set. On the other hand, if I just force the machine to a lower max speed, it will be slow as a turtle when jogging.

So I figured I could just add a header on my generated gcode files with $110 & $111 (slow max speed to start a cut) commands and a footer with $110 & $111 initial values (fast max speed after the cut is finished), but GRBL is complaining with errors saying that $ command is an invalidad statement (error:3) so I guess system commands are not allowed at gcode runtime. 

What can I do now? I'd like to have an automatic workaround for this and not have to execute macros everytime to overcome this. 

Sorry if this is not supposed to go on this place, but from my ignorance I think this is a GRBL limitation not a gcode generating software problem.

Thanks in advance.


Edit: I just realized I could overcome this problem by just drawing a line from the origin to the first cut point to avoid the aforementioned rapid move. If you determine a better solution, please let me know.

title: Hard Limit Triggered, Motors loose holding torque and drop Z axis.  Way to avoid?
body:
In grbl when I have hard limits enabled and it a limit switch the machine enters alarm state.
In the time it takes to send \x18 and then send $X the holding torque is dropped from the motors.  
As a result my z-axis is dropped!

Is there a setting in grbl that I can tinker to maintain holding torque during alarm and reset?  I tried looking over config.h, limits.c, and motion_control.c but am having trouble finding what I am looking for


-note: I understand this is less of an issue and more of a question but I cannot find the existence of a grbl question forum so I am posting here.  If this is incorrect, my apologies.

title: G04 min value
body:
Hello,

I have a grbl 1.1f, I want to use G04 command and I figured out if I send G04 P1 - it is delay for 1 second. I need milliseconds so I send values from 0.0012 to 0.2500.

The problem is that I notice only 5 or 4 different delay times, as if it interprets only in 50 ms increments (I used sound scope and it clearly shows 5 layer graduation). Is this due to grbl or hardware?
Maybe some advice how can I achieve 1ms(or even better 0.1ms) dwell times?

Simas

title: is it possible to have homing / call homing cycle if my axis are not set up with the 'hand cartesian rule'
body:
My system has a peculiar drive such that the y and z axis are sharing the same belt.  Therefore if I want to move 
`y+1` this equates to be `y+1, z+1` If I want to move `z+1` then I move `z+1` and `y+1` etc.

My question is, is it possible to still use homing?  
Is there a grbl command to represent home that I can call in a stream?

for example I can manually stream the gcode to max out the x,y,z axis in the way I know my machine has to move. If I wrote a function that sent gcode to move (in my weird way) is there a way to hit a limit switch and tell grbl my machine is at home?

title: Can I ask, what compiler setup you are using for this? I need to add a tool change to this and I have to setup compilers with IDE etc...
Missing X real time status report per second
body:
Hello,

Thank you for your excellent work on this project. 
I'm using GRBL paired with GRBL-plotter and I often get a message saying that we are missing real time status report. I wanted to know how badly does this affect the system and what could cause this problem ?
For information I am not using an arduino board but one designed by a co-worker. Apart from this, everything seems to be working just fine.

Thank you for your help.

title: Homing refuses to work
body:
After fixing the noise issue in my engraver the $H Command locks up Grbl.
Here is my config:

  | $0 | Step pulse time | 10 | microseconds | Sets time length per step. Minimum 3usec.
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
  | $1 | Step idle delay | 25 | milliseconds | Sets a short hold delay when stopping to let dynamics settle before disabling steppers. Value 255 keeps motors enabled with no delay.
  | $2 | Step pulse invert | 0 | mask | Inverts the step signal. Set axis bit to invert (00000ZYX).
  | $3 | Step direction invert | 1 | mask | Inverts the direction signal. Set axis bit to invert (00000ZYX).
  | $4 | Invert step enable pin | 0 | boolean | Inverts the stepper driver enable pin signal.
  | $5 | Invert limit pins | 0 | boolean | Inverts the all of the limit input pins.
  | $6 | Invert probe pin | 0 | boolean | Inverts the probe input pin signal.
  | $10 | Status report options | 1 | mask | Alters data included in status reports.
  | $11 | Junction deviation | 0,010 | millimeters | Sets how fast Grbl travels through consecutive motions. Lower value slows it down.
  | $12 | Arc tolerance | 0,002 | millimeters | Sets the G2 and G3 arc tracing accuracy based on radial error. Beware: A very small value may effect performance.
  | $13 | Report in inches | 0 | boolean | Enables inch units when returning any position and rate value that is not a settings value.
  | $20 | Soft limits enable | 0 | boolean | Enables soft limits checks within machine travel and sets alarm when exceeded. Requires homing.
  | $21 | Hard limits enable | 1 | boolean | Enables hard limits. Immediately halts motion and throws an alarm when switch is triggered.
  | $22 | Homing cycle enable | 1 | boolean | Enables homing cycle. Requires limit switches on all axes.
  | $23 | Homing direction invert | 11 | mask | Homing searches for a switch in the positive direction. Set axis bit (00000ZYX) to search in negative direction.
  | $24 | Homing locate feed rate | 25,000 | mm/min | Feed rate to slowly engage limit switch to determine its location accurately.
  | $25 | Homing search seek rate | 500,000 | mm/min | Seek rate to quickly find the limit switch before the slower locating phase.
  | $26 | Homing switch debounce delay | 250 | milliseconds | Sets a short delay between phases of homing cycle to let a switch debounce.
  | $27 | Homing switch pull-off distance | 1,000 | millimeters | Retract distance after triggering switch to disengage it. Homing will fail if switch isn't cleared.
  | $30 | Maximum spindle speed | 1000 | RPM | Maximum spindle speed. Sets PWM to 100% duty cycle.
  | $31 | Minimum spindle speed | 0 | RPM | Minimum spindle speed. Sets PWM to 0.4% or lowest duty cycle.
  | $32 | Laser-mode enable | 0 | boolean | Enables laser mode. Consecutive G1/2/3 commands will not halt when spindle speed is changed.
  | $100 | X-axis travel resolution | 250,000 | step/mm | X-axis travel resolution in steps per millimeter.
  | $101 | Y-axis travel resolution | 250,000 | step/mm | Y-axis travel resolution in steps per millimeter.
  | $102 | Z-axis travel resolution | 250,000 | step/mm | Z-axis travel resolution in steps per millimeter.
  | $110 | X-axis maximum rate | 500,000 | mm/min | X-axis maximum rate. Used as G0 rapid rate.
  | $111 | Y-axis maximum rate | 500,000 | mm/min | Y-axis maximum rate. Used as G0 rapid rate.
  | $112 | Z-axis maximum rate | 500,000 | mm/min | Z-axis maximum rate. Used as G0 rapid rate.
  | $120 | X-axis acceleration | 50,000 | mm/sec^2 | X-axis acceleration. Used for motion planning to not exceed motor torque and lose steps.
  | $121 | Y-axis acceleration | 50,000 | mm/sec^2 | Y-axis acceleration. Used for motion planning to not exceed motor torque and lose steps.
  | $122 | Z-axis acceleration | 50,000 | mm/sec^2 | Z-axis acceleration. Used for motion planning to not exceed motor torque and lose steps.
  | $130 | X-axis maximum travel | 200,000 | millimeters | Maximum X-axis travel distance from homing switch. Determines valid machine space for soft-limits and homing search distances.
  | $131 | Y-axis maximum travel | 200,000 | millimeters | Maximum Y-axis travel distance from homing switch. Determines valid machine space for soft-limits and homing search distances.
  | $132 | Z-axis maximum travel | 200,000 | millimeters | Maximum Z-axis travel distance from homing switch. Determines valid machine space for soft-limits and homing search distances.

Does anybody have an Idea why this is happening?

title: FR: Ability to tell grbl that homing limit switches are not at machine zero?
body:
Hello! 
I've installed limit switches at max coordinates of the machine for homing. Now after homing my machine coordinates are zero (actually -1,-1,-1 because of 1mm pulloff). 
But now every time I move to machine zero on any of the axis, my limit switches trip and grbl goes into alarm, requiring to reset!
Is it supposed to work this way? Are there any parameters that can change the position of homing limit switches to be not at zero? If not, than consider this issue a feature request!

This seems important, because some popular programs assume that machine zero is reachable and "safe":
* Candle goes to G53 G0 Z0 as a "safe position"
* Autodesk Fusion 360's grbl post-processor goes to machine 0,0 at the end of the job

title: MKS SBase 1.3 with external stepper controllers
body:
Hello, had a working configuration with the original mks sbase firmware and using external stepper controllers. My original config.txt looked like this:

`# Stepper module pins ( ports, and pin numbers, appending "!" to the number will invert a pin )
alpha_step_pin                               2.0              # Pin for alpha stepper step signal
alpha_dir_pin                                0.5              # Pin for alpha stepper direction
alpha_en_pin                                 0.4              # Pin for alpha enable pin
alpha_current                                0.5             # X stepper motor current
alpha_max_rate                               7000.0          # mm/min

beta_step_pin                                2.1              # Pin for beta stepper step signal
beta_dir_pin                                 0.11!             # Pin for beta stepper direction
beta_en_pin                                  0.10             # Pin for beta enable
beta_current                                 0.5           # Y stepper motor current
beta_max_rate                                7000.0          # mm/min

gamma_step_pin                               2.2              # Pin for gamma stepper step signal
gamma_dir_pin                                0.20             # Pin for gamma stepper direction
gamma_en_pin                                 0.19             # Pin for gamma enable
gamma_current                                0.5              # Z stepper motor current
gamma_max_rate                               500.0            # mm/min`


I flashed the grbl-lpc firmware using the beta10_4axes/mks_sbase_firmware.bin renamed to firmware.bin, and am using Openbuilds CONTROL software. When connecting, board responds with:

I've set $140-$142 with the value of 0.5, since I'm using external stepper controllers and I properly set the steps per mm as well.  Any attempts to jog and the machine just sits there.

title: Spindle refuses to spin after limit switches installed
body:
I've a CNC with a WoodPecker 3.4 board, I've installed all limit switches (2 by axis), I've put X limit switches to Z limit labelled pins like other people advised. My homing is working great but my spindle refuses to work if my Z limit switches are connected (to X limit labels).

What can I do ?

title: No clear PUL signal - Stepper motor driver doesn't recognize steps!
body:
Hi there,

Stepper motor driver doesn't recognize step due to an unclear PUL signal. I suppose that my wiring is correct - when it write a little Arduino "Sketch" using the AccelStepper all the steppers are working correctly because the is a clear rectangled signal.
With Grbl flashed (0.9, 1.1) it's like a "baseline" at 0V/5V depending of the bit flag settings for inverting but with a tiny signal "on top". 

Attached you find the 2 signals im referring to. Im trying to get my (second) machine moving for days now. I'm very grateful for every advice. I just don't understand this behavior.
I've got NEMA 17 motors with Stepperonline Drivers, DM320T and DM 332T (with octocupplers).

BTW $0=50 doesn't change anything, the "on top" signal is just getting longer.... and I also tried with a brand new Arduino...

title: G49 triggers an error number 24
body:
Combining a G49 gcode (Cancel Tool Length Compensation) with a G0 / G1 / G2 / G3 in the same block produces an error 24 (Two G-code commands that both require the use of the XYZ axis words were detected in the block). This seems strange as a G49 does not use the axes. The issue can be reproduced simply with the following code:
`G0 G49`
`M2`
Is this behaviour intended?

title: Axis lenght off by 2 mm
body:
My machine has an X axis travel length of 350mm.
I set the X-axis length in config:
$130=350.000
but when I issue G0X-350 I get Alarm:2: G-code motion target exceeds machine travel. Ok, I thought it may be an "off by one" problem, and sent the machine to G0X-349, but got the same error. G0X-348 worked. It seems I must set the axis limit to the actutal length +2mm.

Why this !?

title: Why the machine Homing zero on the (top right) corner?
body:
I've setup the homing for my machine and was intrigued on why the homing zero on the top right corner. Usually when you X+ or Y+ it goes to the right or top, I would assume the zero point it would be on the lower left corner. Is there a way to change that?

My motor directions are correct so I know this is not the problem.
If I set $23=1 it will zero on the top left which is also not what I believe is correct.

Am I doing something wrong? Is there a way to zero on the lower left corner?

title: #error "Required HOMING_CYCLE_0 not defined."
body:
@chamnit I know the issue has been discussed in here but I've tried everything and still can't compile. I've removed all instances of Arduino including the ~/Library/Arduino15 and ˜/Documents/Arduino, killed the process, deleted the Arduino app and installed all fresh.

Every time I make a change on the config.h I get this error. The change is correct as I'm pretty much commenting the two entries for Homing with 3 axis and removing the comment for the two entries for homing with two axis.

I've noticed that even if I quit and kill any of the Arduino IDE process and replace the grbl library in my ~/Documents/Arduino/libraries/ with an untouched new grbl code and try to compile I get the same error however, if I do the same with a 0.9j it shows that the variable have been modified/redefined but with the 1.1 it just gives an error.

I've tried with the 0.9j and it works but not with the 1.1.

Can you help me with this?

Below is what I get which is a problem that has been discussed with others. Hope someone can shed some light in here.

In file included from /Users/fviana/Documents/Arduino/libraries/grbl/config.h:30:0,

title: Develop
body:
Init platformio project

  • Agrego platformio.ini

title: Plain GRBL and tool change (beginner question)
body:
Hi,

for some time I´ve been working with a X/Y/Z edge finder like this and it worked

![1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44340656/88464955-12572d80-cebf-11ea-8545-5d8781342674.JPG)


Now I bought this little thing in order to be able to change a tool during machining a job.

![88403932-78638800-cdcd-11ea-975d-122af5827a54](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44340656/88464956-15521e00-cebf-11ea-988b-c2da11fc86e8.JPG)

Seems "G43.1 Dynamic tool length offset" is a subject here. In other forums they use some scripting language to calculate "old" and "new" offset and tell GRBL to use the difference. But with a simple GRBL G code sender without interaction features?

I just can trigger special and static(!) G code in case "M6" command comes up. Fusion 360 offers tool changes like "T1 M6" so theoretically it should have a chance.

It´d be nice to

* home X/Y/Z
* use a the aluminum plate to find G54
* start with tool #1
 (works until here)
* move to tool change position
 (triggered by M6, works)
* measure (whatever that means) the new tool
* go on with machining

Or am I on the wrong track?

The basic procedure after fixing the work piece would also be helpful.

Thanks in advance

title: update to 1.1h and board isnt working anymore
body: Hi, I updated my 328P-based board and my gcode sender ony sends an alarm. Do I need to change settings when updating to 1.1h?

title: GRBL 1.1: Simulation of NC file is correct, but real toolpath is crazy
body:
Hi everyone,
I've experience a problem with Arduino UNO and GRBL v1.1e, currently milling/engraving a motorcycle's logo.
This logo has a pocketed frame around, which is partly curved and partly straight. (actually, it's the H-D emblem).
The milling simulation looks 100% OK, but in reality, approx. after engraving half of that pocket, the curved part of the pocket (lower left area of workpiece) becomes stretched in X-axis (tool paths split to then end of the curve, but very smooth?!). At the end of the job, the left vertical part of the frame has twice of the expected width (half pocket has an offset about 2 mm). But on the left half of the workpiece, everything is still OK! (the stretching effect on the left side is compensated again on the toolpath to the right?!
It can't be lost steps, because the toolpath is extended in one direction (-X), and in opposit direction (+X), the toolpath is shortened, and the most right point has no offset.
The upper left curved part starts with split paths, and when the curve ends, the toolpaths are no more splitted!
Is GRBL making rounding errors, calculation errors, having timing problems?
Steppers sound very smooth, axes moving easy (not blocking), no backlash (pre-loaded ball screws). Moderate feed rates (tried different speeds, nothing changes).

Has anyone experienced something similar?

Regards,
Chris

title: work position of y axis starts at 10mm when connected
body:
Greetings and thank you for taking time to read this problem i am encountering.
Whenever i connect my grbl loaded(1.1) arduino nano to UGS it connects but the work position is always at positive 10mm.
I tried to find what is making this happen but no success. Any kind of help, tip or suggestion is appreciated.
I have attached a capture of the UGS.

Thanks in advance.
![issueworkpos1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40540237/86476427-23030080-bd64-11ea-94b6-daba7cacfbd6.PNG)

title: New User and Arduino serial monitor - how?
body:
https://github.com/gnea/grbl/wiki/Grbl-v1.1-Interface
"You just need to connect your Arduino to your computer with a USB cable. Use any standard serial terminal program to connect to Grbl, such as: the Arduino IDE serial monitor"
So I did that, and it didn't.
I had to run a sketch (BareMinimum) on the Arduino to enable me to open the serial monitor. 
I put into the Send box, $<enter>, then $$<enter> - nothing happened.

Connection is fine using the UGS (GUI ), so obviously I am missing a vital step.  My aim is to write a Python program to control the machine using the GRBL, Arduino and gShield.

"Just" is a bit of an exaggeration.
I am running a Arduino Uno with a gShield and GRBL 1.1.  The baud rate and COM seem to match OK.

title: Homing in X direction doesn't work
body:
grbl version: 1.1h on Woodpecker 3.2 controller. 

$20=0
$21=0 
$22=1

Odd problem - I recently put in a set of limit switches, set up the homing dir mask, etc.  Sending a $H command starts the whole process correctly, with the Z axis movement.  As soon as that completes, the machine stops and seemingly hangs (does not respond to any further command inputs via serial, does not produce any messages on the serial terminal). 

I modified config.h to enable separate X, Y and Z homing and discovered that Z and Y homing work correctly, while X homing always produces a "stuck" machine (steppers powered, controller unresponsive to any commands). The only way out of this seems to be a hard-reset. 

X movement using something like G1 X25 F100 works properly. 

I have tried:

- swapping A4988 driver modules (just for luck) - no effect
- testing with hard limits ($21=1) - this works as expected, i.e. 
G1 X 50 F250   gets the X axis moving, and the moment I manually trigger the X limit switch, the system stops and an alarm message is produced. 
- doing a $HX, and triggering the X limit switch by hand to simulate that the head unit "reached" the limit switch, etc - but the controller never comes out of its seemingly locked state (no "ok" message). 
- checking if it's false-triggering from the limit switches (they are configured as NO - I added 2.2K pull-up resistors to ensure there's little chance of noise ingress; there's already an RC network on each of the pins) - seems clean.  
 
In short - it's only the X-homing that doesn't work, and anything that "calls" the routine results in a controller hang. 

I will be happy to try out any mods (software or hardware) to solve this problem, i.e. could this be a solder bridge issue, causing an interrupt that is only allowed through during X-homing?  I might be able to find this if I knew which interrupts / pins to look at...

title: Loss of Position on Resume After Safety Door Feedhold
body:
I'm trying to track down an issue I'm having with feedhold parking / resume.
Basically, on resuming after the parking is completed, I'm losing about one mm (Z ends up too high).  I am retracing 5mm at a feed of 100mm/min and then parking at Machine Z-5mm at 500mm/min.
My Z is a ballscrew that has no issues with backlash or lost steps, and those feedrates are well below my max.  This is a very repeatable issue.
If I run the same motion through a macro or similar, I do not see the same loss of Z position.  I can run 
```
G91
G1Z5F100
G90
G53Z-5F500
```
and back to Z0 all day without any loss of Z position.
I seem to have narrowed it down to the RESUME where the position is lost, not on the actual parking.
Any thoughts?
Thanks!

[VER:1.1f.20170731:]
[OPT:VP,15,128]

title: Limits issue
body:
Hello everyone 

I try to add limit switch to my plotter. 

I use a [laserAxe](https://www.google.com/imgres?imgurl=https%3A%2F%2Fimages-na.ssl-images-amazon.com%2Fimages%2FI%2F61p1rHjt5EL._AC_SX522_.jpg&imgrefurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FEngraving-Cutting-Machine-Engraver-Controller%2Fdp%2FB07QL7C7F8&tbnid=YaGvkBPPZUO5vM&vet=12ahUKEwjQsqOSuobpAhVPgRoKHQi-AUYQMygKegUIARCEAg..i&docid=Y4PHE8NxPYdbZM&w=522&h=327&q=laseraxe&client=firefox-b-d&ved=2ahUKEwjQsqOSuobpAhVPgRoKHQi-AUYQMygKegUIARCEAg) controller with only two axis

On this board, limits are wired to pin 9, 10 and 12 
so I changed changed cpu_map.h like this : 
```
#define LIMIT_DDR DDRB
```

title: Servo not working on CNC Shield V4
body:
Hi !

I'm creating a CNC Plotter with 2 Bipolar Steppers for X & Y and a servo as a Z axis for the pen.

I bought a CNC Shield V4 ([link](https://fr.banggood.com/Geekcreit-CNC-Shield-V4-With-Nano-3_0-A4988-Stepper-Motor-Driver-Board-For-Arduino-products-that-work-with-official-Arduino-boards-p-1250215.html?rmmds=myorder&cur_warehouse=CN)) on banggood. **Disclaimer : don't buy this board,  it's full of bugs.**

I installed grbl on the Arduino Nano and did the following things : 
- In cpu_map.h : Invert the pinout between X_STEP_BIT, Y_STEP_BIT Z_STEP_BIT and X_DIRECTION_BIT, Y_DIRECTION_BIT, Z_DIRECTION_BIT  (as I said this board is garbage 😂, they even failed for that)
- In config.h : comment VARIABLE_SPINDLE to disable it

So I have connected the servo on Z+ which is connected to pin 11 of the Nano. And in Universal Gcode Sender, I enter the commands "M3" or  "M5" but the servo is not moving at all. I tried with grbl 1.1f and 1.1h

I've already tested my servo on the pin 11 of a spare Arduino Nano, it works fine.  

Do you have any ideas or something I have missed...

Thank you,

title: ST, EN and DIR Sink instead of Source
body:
I'm trying to integrate with the Geckodrive GR214V, but it appears to want a sink input.

[Page 5, https://www.geckodrive.com/amfile/file/download/file_id/32/product_id/49/]
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10651270/80230227-fad89080-8694-11ea-886d-d0f3c5cc340f.png)

Is it possible to include a build flag that changes the DIO mode of the step, enable and direction pins to assume an external pullup exists, and in turn sink current when output = LOW?

[EDIT]
Issue was wiring. ATmega does pull to ground when OUTPUT = LOW, the wiring situation gave me the impression it just floated the output.

title: Resume after Pause behaves irrational
body:
Hi!
I use OpenCNCPilot GUI (OCP) together with GRBL V1.1f.

OCP has an option to pause the streaming of a gcode file.
When streaming gcode is paused, one can issue jog commands.
After that one can resume the streaming job. 
The Gcode in the file has absolute coordinates.

What happened:
I paused the gcode job, the GRBL buffer is depleted, the milling bit sits 8 mm deep in the workpiece.
I jog to Z somewhere above the workpiece to have a look on what the bit has done so far to the workpiece.
After that I issue "resume".
The bit is lowered to its previous height and the job went on.

Next time, same procedure, "pause", issue jog commands for Z but then jog to X somewhere to positive X values, so I can even better see what has been done so far.

Now the problem:
After issuing "resume" the bit is lowered to its former Z position (into the workpiece at the current, displaced, X position) and then it moved to the coords which are given be the next gcode command... ruining the workpiece.

My expectation was, that first the X and Y coords would be restored, after that Z should be restored.

Is there a means of parametrizing that?
Or is it mandatory to not jog around during a running gcode streaming job?

Thanks!

Harald

title: Coolant Enable Quickly Toggled on Power-up
body:
I just completed a controller build using the latest committed version of GRBL with the dual axis homing enabled (Protoneer CNC v3.51 option) and am having an issue with the coolant output.

When I power up, the coolant output is quickly toggled on and off. It also toggles on and off when I open UGS but I am assuming that may be due to UGS issuing a reset. This causes my IOT relay to quickly cycle, at least once, and turn on my shopvac.

The output works normally using the M8 and M9 command just fine, it's just a strange boot-up issue.

I am assuming this is just a start-up state for D13 being one thing until the dual axis config takes over the output pin but have yet to confirm that.

I'm trying to find a config.h setting that would correct this but haven't been successful yet.

Also, on a related note, the commit log on GitHub has the step/dir ports reversed from how the code has it.

My previous installation was using USE_SPINDLE_DIR_AS_ENABLE_PIN switch in config.h.  And it worked great. If I use this switch AND  ENABLE_DUAL_AXIS switch, will D13 pin be for spindle enable?  If not, how would I do that? 

Thanks

title: Dual Axis Homing offset
body:
I am running grbl 1.1h with dual axis homing setup on the Y axis.  Everything is working great with the exception of one thing.  I have noticed that when I home Y, even though the homing cycles homes each Y motor independently as expected, it seems to add an offset to Y that it does not add to Y2.  This means that one side is always around .5mm out of square.  Is there a setting that I am unable to find to adjust this offset?  I have worked with other firmwares and know that some offer and offset setting to help get things perfectly square.  I am also curious if the "homing switch pull off distance" may have something to do with this.  Mine is set to 1mm and possibly the y2 side is not having this applied but my gantry is just strong enough to move Y2 back .5mm when Y goes back the 1mm.

All the hard work that goes into GRBL is greatly appreciated and I am loving it so far!  Just need this last kink worked out I am at good to go!

title: How detect a command has been actually carried out?
body:
Hi all,
I am working on integrating a GRBL controlled CNC axis into an application. Generally the serial communication works well, but I haven't found a satisfactory solution to the following problem:

Most GRBL commands, like G0X... will be acknowledged by "ok" when received/buffered, but not when actually carried out and finished. if I intend to send a sequence like this:

    $110=300
    G0X400
    $110=80
    G0X0

and send the next command after I have received "ok", the second set speed ($110=80) command will end up in error 8, since I may change speed only if the machine has finished processing the previous G0 command.

I tried several approaches like to wait for "idle" and "run" state by polling the machine state using "?" commands, but the results were unsatisfactory.

Can anyone advise me how I can organize my communication so I can reliably detect when GRBL is ready to receive the next command?

Thnx, Armin

title: NC Limit switches not working properly
body:
After spending a whole day trying to resolve this issue, I dare to bug you. I set up GRBL on an Arduino Uno to run a 3 axis CNC mill. The steppers run fine, G0 commands work, now I added end-stop switches (NC type, wired to GND).

Since then the machine will always throw an Alarm:1 when any Stepper starts.

My setup is:

$21=1
$5=1

everything else at the defaults. See the end of this post for all config values.

If I enter any motion command, e.g. G0 X -1, the motor does a faint "click" and stops immedately, and grbl throws "ALARM 1". It obviously thinks, it has hit and end-stop, though there isn't one. This happens in the same manner every time (tried at least 50 times now ...). Here's a log of such a "session":

ok
?<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|Ov:100,100,100>
G0 X 10
ok
ALARM:1
[MSG:Reset to continue]
Grbl 1.1h ['$' for help]
[MSG:'$H'|'$X' to unlock]
?<Alarm|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|WCO:0.000,0.000,0.000>

You see, the machine didn't even move a step.

Already tried/ruled out:
- reset the error, machine ready, waited a while, nothing happened, then pressed any one of the end stops by hand: "ALARM:1" appears at once, like expected. So I guess that the switches are wired correctly. 
- defective Arduino Uno. I wrote myself a little sketch which enables pins 9,10,12 with INPUT_PULLUP, and I digitalRead the correct states: LOW if the NC switch is not pressed, HIGH if it is pressed.
- just for fun, I added noise suppression and debouncing via 470 Ohms to +5V and 10nF to GND like shown in the docs, problem persists.
- measured the voltage at pin 9,10 and 12 using an oscilloscope, all three are at 0V, and jump to 5V if I press any switch. No spikes noticeable.
- finally I loaded the very same hardware with a crude "Bit-Banging" stepper control routine which uses digitalRead after every Step to check whether a switch has triggered. The routine is meant to "torture" my setup, running the stepper at full speed approx 10cm in one direction, and back, in an endless loop. I let it run for several hours, and got not a single end-stop alert. Not one. Just to check, I pressed an end-stop manually, and the stepper halted at once, so the switches are working.  
- I also disconnected the stepper, and let the Arduino send the signals into hyperspace, the error came immedately. If it is any kind of interference, maybe with the ENA signal, it's really a nasty bugger.

AT this point I thought I ruled out any hardware issues, which shifts attention to a configuration issue. But I followed your docs, and double-and triple checked everything, and found no error, nothing smelling like it could make GRBL something like hyper-sensitive when it comes to checking end-stops. In parallel, my oscilloscope was running all the time, and I never noticed any glitch in the signals.

Guys, I am stuck, and any help would be greatly appreciated.
For completeness, here is my complete config:
ok
$0=10
$1=25
$2=0
$3=0
$4=0
$5=1
$6=0
$10=17
$11=0.010
$12=0.002
$13=0
$20=0
$21=1
$22=0
$23=0
$24=25.000
$25=500.000
$26=250
$27=1.000
$30=1000
$31=0
$32=0
$100=80.000
$101=250.000
$102=250.000
$110=500.000
$111=500.000
$112=500.000
$120=5.000
$121=10.000
$122=10.000
$130=200.000
$131=200.000
$132=200.000
ok

Any ideas?

title: Dual axis problems
body:
Hi!

I'm currently working to get the dual axis configuration working. But it's not yet working as expected.
My config:
I have an UNO with CNC shield that was working fine with the 1.1g version.
I have 2 motors on the y axis.
All endstops are NC and the second motor on the y axis (Motor A on the shield) has also an end-stop in series with the z axis.
When i trigger the endstop on Motor Y the status shows Y
When i trigger the endstop on Motor A the status shows YZ

[config.zip](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/files/4008128/config.zip)
#define ENABLE_DUAL_AXIS
#define DUAL_AXIS_SELECT  Y_AXIS  // Must be either X_AXIS or Y_AXIS

Turn off cloning A from Y-axis by removing jumpers on the CNC shield.
Connect pin SpnEn  to A.Step
Connect pin SpnDir to A.Dir

It looks like the end-stop on Motor Y is ignored. Because on homing it stays moving when the end stop is triggered. Moving is working fine. Only homing seems to have issues.

Does someone has any idea?

Looking at the code in limits.c this looks strange to me, because why take the y axis when the x axis is configured?
`#if (DUAL_AXIS_SELECT == X_AXIS)
      float fail_distance = (-DUAL_AXIS_HOMING_FAIL_AXIS_LENGTH_PERCENT/100.0)*settings.max_travel[Y_AXIS];
    #else
      float fail_distance = (-DUAL_AXIS_HOMING_FAIL_AXIS_LENGTH_PERCENT/100.0)*settings.max_travel[X_AXIS];
    #endif`

title: Wrong text in Release Notes 1.1h?
body:
Hi,

After reading the release notes of 1.1h im wondering if the text below is ok and if text "Y-axis" is wrong and needs to be X-axis. Also i have NC switches so connecting the other switch to the other z pin will not work. Setting this up in serial will be ok i think. Maybe this is also something to mention. TY for all your hard work!

Dual axis homing will automatically abort homing if one limit switch triggers and travels more than 5% (default) of the non-dual axis max travel setting. For example, if the X-axis has dual motors and one X-axis triggers during homing, Grbl will abort 5% of the Y-axis max travel and the other X-axis limit fails to trigger. This will help keep any misconfigurations or failed limit switches from damaging the machine, but not completely eliminate this risk. Please take all precautions and test thouroughly before using this.

title: Bresenham's algorithm for arcs
body:
Hello. I'm from Russia. I use automatic translation from Russian into English, so I apologize if the text is not entirely correct.
I am making my simple Atmega CNC system. I got acquainted with your experience and am going to partially use your ideas, in particular, the ring buffer for receiving program frames from the computer and the ring buffer of the motion planner.
I wonder why you use approximation of arcs by line segments? I think it's hard. Calculation of trigonometric functions is required, and a lot of segments need to be calculated.
After all, there is Bresenham's algorithm for constructing arcs. It happens in integers.
There is also a Michener's algorithm (this is an improved Bresenham algorithm).
In industrial CNC racks, the evaluation function method is also used. It is even simpler than the Bresenham algorithm.
I also found a description of the CNC rack manufactured in the Soviet Union, where the method of a digital differential analyzer in integers was used. I already tried it. At first he simulated on a computer - he drew circles. Then used in the firmware for Atmega. My CNC plotter drew a perfect circle.
If you are interested in these algorithms, I could share my codes.

I have built my first very basic cnc plasma. The cut file, using grbl, frezes at the point the relay fires the plasma on. The same file runs through fine in its entireity without the plasma on.
I installed a sparkfunk relay with a led and the led lights up at points the plasma should fire on all test runs while the plasma is off. title: Homing Issues
body:
Hi there !

I just set up my homemade laser engraver, and everything works fine... except the homing cycle.
When I try to $H, I hear a noise, like one or more steppers tries to move, but I can't see any movement. Then it stops and grbl is launching an ALARM 8.

I have no idea what to do, since my axis moves well in the desired direction (via G91 G0 command).
Here are my settings of grbl :

> 
> $0 = 10    (Step pulse time, microseconds)
> $1 = 25    (Step idle delay, milliseconds)
> $2 = 0    (Step pulse invert, mask)
> $3 = 0    (Step direction invert, mask)
> $4 = 0    (Invert step enable pin, boolean)
> $5 = 1    (Invert limit pins, boolean)
> $6 = 0    (Invert probe pin, boolean)
> $10 = 1    (Status report options, mask)
> $11 = 0.010    (Junction deviation, millimeters)
> $12 = 0.002    (Arc tolerance, millimeters)
> $13 = 0    (Report in inches, boolean)
> $20 = 0    (Soft limits enable, boolean)
> $21 = 0    (Hard limits enable, boolean)
> $22 = 1    (Homing cycle enable, boolean)
> $23 = 1    (Homing direction invert, mask)
> $24 = 25.000    (Homing locate feed rate, mm/min)
> $25 = 500.000    (Homing search seek rate, mm/min)
> $26 = 250    (Homing switch debounce delay, milliseconds)
> $27 = 5.000    (Homing switch pull-off distance, millimeters)
> $30 = 1000    (Maximum spindle speed, RPM)
> $31 = 0    (Minimum spindle speed, RPM)
> $32 = 1    (Laser-mode enable, boolean)
> $100 = 800.000    (X-axis travel resolution, step/mm)
> $101 = 800.000    (Y-axis travel resolution, step/mm)
> $102 = 800.000    (Z-axis travel resolution, step/mm)
> $110 = 500.000    (X-axis maximum rate, mm/min)
> $111 = 500.000    (Y-axis maximum rate, mm/min)
> $112 = 500.000    (Z-axis maximum rate, mm/min)
> $120 = 10.000    (X-axis acceleration, mm/sec^2)
> $121 = 10.000    (Y-axis acceleration, mm/sec^2)
> $122 = 10.000    (Z-axis acceleration, mm/sec^2)
> $130 = 200.000    (X-axis maximum travel, millimeters)
> $131 = 200.000    (Y-axis maximum travel, millimeters)
> $132 = 200.000    (Z-axis maximum travel, millimeters)

This is a picture of the gauntry, if you want to see how my axis are set.
![CNC_Axis](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20611086/68192734-10a4ad00-ffb2-11e9-8992-5bdfaba0f5e3.jpg)
The "home switches" are left for X and up for Y (the tool support is almost at home on the picture), and the are NC (hence the $5=1).

For the hardware, it's an Arduino Uno with a Protoneer CNC Shield. It runs grbl 1.1f and I'm using UGS Platform and SourceRabbit for the communication, with the same result (I even tried the console of the Arduino IDE).

Thanks in advance for any suggestion, advice, corrections, etc. :slightly_smiling_face:

title: Continuous jogging in UGS
body:
I've been struggling trying to implement continuous jogging in UGS in such a way that if the user holds a jog button it will enter continuous mode and should stop once the button is released. 

So it seems to work most of the times, we queue jog commands filling the buffers one command at the time in a fixed interval as long as the jog button is pressed. Once the button is released we'll send a jog cancel command and it stops like expected. 

But I find it difficult to find a good balance keeping the planner buffer filled in GRBL so it will keep jogging at the desired feed rate, and not filling it. It seems like once it's filled it will not be able to cancel and completely clear the planner buffer. I tried following the discussion here #95, but there was no conclusive solution?

When I start jogging the commands are filling the buffers:
```
[verbose] <Idle|MPos:268.290,0.000,0.000|Bf:15,128|FS:0,0>
[verbose] <Idle|MPos:268.290,0.000,0.000|Bf:15,128|FS:0,0>
[verbose] <Idle|MPos:268.290,0.000,0.000|Bf:15,128|FS:0,0>
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:268.310,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:84,0>
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:268.620,0.000,0.000|Bf:12,128|FS:186,0|WCO:0.000,0.000,0.000>
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:269.340,0.000,0.000|Bf:10,128|FS:300,0|Ov:100,100,100>
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:270.480,0.000,0.000|Bf:8,128|FS:426,0>
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:272.040,0.000,0.000|Bf:6,128|FS:546,0>
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:274.020,0.000,0.000|Bf:4,128|FS:672,0>
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:276.420,0.000,0.000|Bf:2,128|FS:792,0>
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
ok
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:279.230,0.000,0.000|Bf:0,128|FS:912,0>
>>> $J=G20G91X1.667F1000
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:282.460,0.000,0.000|Bf:0,128|FS:1038,0>

**** Canceling file transfer. ****
```
Now the cancel jog command (0x85) was issued and it will decelerate:

```
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:286.060,0.000,0.000|Bf:0,128|FS:1110,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:289.690,0.000,0.000|Bf:0,128|FS:990,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:292.950,0.000,0.000|Bf:0,128|FS:864,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:295.730,0.000,0.000|Bf:0,128|FS:744,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:298.130,0.000,0.000|Bf:0,128|FS:624,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:300.170,0.000,0.000|Bf:0,128|FS:498,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:301.780,0.000,0.000|Bf:0,128|FS:372,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:302.890,0.000,0.000|Bf:0,128|FS:258,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:303.640,0.000,0.000|Bf:0,128|FS:132,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:303.990,0.000,0.000|Bf:0,128|FS:0,0>
```

But then I'll receive an ok-message and start accelerating again and it will keep running:
```
ok
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:304.070,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:96,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:304.490,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:216,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:305.330,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:336,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:306.570,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:456,0|Ov:100,100,100>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:308.210,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:576,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:310.260,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:696,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:312.740,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:822,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:315.630,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:942,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:318.940,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:1062,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:322.670,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:1188,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:326.850,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:1308,0>
[verbose] <Jog|MPos:331.350,0.000,0.000|Bf:14,128|FS:1428,0>
```

I know that in this example I'm using a too large step size and an unreasonable feed rate, but this was only to illustrate a problem that would otherwise be intermittent.

We could probably work around this issue in UGS and keep track of the planner buffer utilisation. But this would require our users to have the setting $10=3 so I don't find that optimal. Do you have any other ideas?

I've got the same results in 1.1e.20161219 and 1.1h.20190825

title: Where to ask detailed questions about GRBL code (for a custom GRBL machine)?
body:
Hi there, I don't have any technical "issues" with GRBL, but I have rather detailed questions about the GRBL code (v1.1), I'm not sure where to ask them. I have a custom GRBL machine. It has X / Y axes, no laser, no spindle, no printer, but it has several servos. The servo motion is isolated, i.e. the servos are never used at the same time as steppers. Hardware-wise everything works. I want to address the servos using the same gcode as steppers, so I modified the GRBL code. The gcode command I "adopted" for servo control is M3, with the "T", "S" and "F" parameters as follows: e.g. M3 T0 S30 F20.  M3 - set servo position, T0 - servo ID is 0, S30 - set the servo to 30 deg angle, F20 - servo movement speed. If I issue this command from a Gcode sender (not as part of a gcode file), everything works fine. But if I include my servo commands in a gcode file, things get messed up with servos: incorrect angles, missed commands etc (regular gcode works fine) The problem I have is that I don't quite grasp how the gcode "planner" works, and how it relates to the current "state" and the parsed "gc_block". I.e. I don't know how to correctly deal with gcode blocks, so that buffered servo commands are executed properly when streamed from a file. The code I'm dealing with is mostly in "gcode.c", STEP 4: EXECUTE. 

If there is a GRBL programmer who is willing to answer a few specialized questions (either here, or privately, via email), please let me know. Thanks.

title: Is it normal that Alarm mode is on, every time you open a new serial connection?
body:
I am trying to programmatically small batches of gcode commands, via grbl's `stream.py`.

The problem I have is: _every time_ I open a new serial connection, "Alarm Mode" is on - the device requires either rehoming, or a "$X", every single time I just open a serial connection to the device. (e.g `screen /dev/ttyUSB0 11520`)

I have tried adding "$X" as the first command in my list of gcodes to send, in the hope that it would turn off the alarm when connecting, but this doesn't seem to work.

How can I simply stream a list of gcode's to the device, if homing is enabled?  Homing every single time is not a workable solution.

title: Z axis not moving right after another axis stopped
body:

The problem: Z axis is not moving, right after one of the other axes stopped. So e.g. the mill moves it's planar position to where it should drill, but Z won't move downwards there.
BUT if there is only a fraction of a second delay in between stopping X/Y and moving Z, it moves without issues.
I already tried hard-coding a delay in grbl in various locations, only resulting in stutteringly motions, when milling circles.

My question to someone, who knows and understands the code better than i do: where does it make sense to put a hard-coded delay, so it will only delay right before a Z movement?

D:\Documents\Arduino\libraries\grbl\report.c: In function 'report_realtime_status':

D:\Documents\Arduino\libraries\grbl\report.c:654:1: error: expected declaration or statement at end of input

 }

This is because in the report.c library, the closing bracket "}" is missing on line 581: 

`if (bit_istrue(lim_pin_state,bit(X_AXIS))) { serial_write('X') ;`

Adding it solves the problem.

title: Clobbering pull-up resistors.
body:
**EDIT** the first part is not valid. I’m leaving it here for clarity when reading the responses but it really should be ignored.

The method used to set bits on the IO ports clobbers any pull-up resistor settings for other bits on the port.
Setting multiple bits simultaneously with a single statement results in machine code being generated that modifies unintended bits.

Suppose bit 7 on port A is being used as an input, with a pull-up; and bits 2 and 4 are being used as an output, initialized like so:
```
DDRA = (1<<2) | (1<<4);
PORTA = (1<<7);
```

OK, now some external hardware pulls pin A7 low.

Then, while it's being held low, bit values for A2 & A4 is set (high or low doesn't matter... but I'll show the high case).
`PORTA |= ((1<<2) | (1<<4));`

This results in machine code that reads the port; does a bitwise or with the value of ((1<<2) | (1<<4)); and writes that back. This will occur even if it's a variable being used to store which bits to turn on, and the variable only ever has one bit turned on in it.

The problem is that the value for bit 7 was read as low, and writing that back results in disabling the pull-up resistor on that pin.

To avoid this the bits for the pins need to be written individually:
```
PORTA |= (1<<2);
PORTA |= (1<<4);
```

which compiles to:

```
  sbi 34-0x20,2
  sbi 34-0x20,4

```
For variables an if statement  must be used:
```
  if(q & (1<<2)) PORTA |= 1<<2; else PORTA &=~ (1<<2);
  if(q & (1<<4)) PORTA |= 1<<4; else PORTA &=~ (1<<4);

```

Beware that using an ?: operator and then using the result value of the operator generates machine code that has this problem:

```
uint8_t foo(uint8_t q)
{
    return (q & (1<<3))?(PORTA |= 1<<3):(PORTA &=~ (1<<3));
}
```

compiles to:
```
foo:
  sbrs r24,3
  rjmp .L2
  in r24,34-0x20
  ori r24,lo8(8)
  out 34-0x20,r24
  ret
.L2:
  in r24,34-0x20
  andi r24,lo8(-9)
  out 34-0x20,r24
  ret

```
Note the separate in, ori, and out instructions generated.

**EDIT** I _think_ the rest is still valid:

Also, a related issue was spotted:

STEP_PULSE_DELAY potentially clobbers any bits that are also on the port(s) that change state between the main ISR(TIMER1_COMPA_vect) firing and the delayed ISR(TIMER0_COMPA_vect) firing.

1) The main ISR stores the value of the entire port into st.step_bits:
`      st.step_bits = (STEP_PORT & ~STEP_MASK) | st.step_outbits; // Store out_bits to prevent overwriting.`
2) Some other event happens (ISR firing after the sei() call?) and one of the port bits not allocated to step outputs changes state.
3) The delayed ISR(TIMER0_COMPA_vect) fires, and reads the old value of the bit(s) in question from st.step_bits.
4) The bits are then clobbered by being written to by the ISR.
`      STEP_PORT = st.step_bits; // Begin step pulse.`


... I think the proper way to do this is to not store the entire port value, but just the step bits that should be pulsed. Also, care must be excersized such that the code that is used resolves to sbi & cbi instructions so that any pull-ups on the port are not accedentally enabled or disabled.

1) In main ISR(TIMER1_COMPA_vect):
`      st.step_bits = st.step_outbits; // Store out_bits to for delay.`
2) In the delayed ISR(TIMER0_COMPA_vect):
```
      if(st.step_bits & (1<<STEP_BIT(X_AXIS))) STEP_PORT |= (1<<STEP_BIT(X_AXIS)); else STEP_PORT &= ~(1<<STEP_BIT(X_AXIS));
      if(st.step_bits & (1<<STEP_BIT(Y_AXIS))) STEP_PORT |= (1<<STEP_BIT(Y_AXIS)); else STEP_PORT &= ~(1<<STEP_BIT(Y_AXIS));
      if(st.step_bits & (1<<STEP_BIT(Z_AXIS))) STEP_PORT |= (1<<STEP_BIT(Z_AXIS)); else STEP_PORT &= ~(1<<STEP_BIT(Z_AXIS));

```
For the non-delayed case, obviously, just set the bits like so:

```
      if(st.step_outbits & (1<<STEP_BIT(X_AXIS))) STEP_PORT |= (1<<STEP_BIT(X_AXIS)); else STEP_PORT &= ~(1<<STEP_BIT(X_AXIS));
      if(st.step_outbits & (1<<STEP_BIT(Y_AXIS))) STEP_PORT |= (1<<STEP_BIT(Y_AXIS)); else STEP_PORT &= ~(1<<STEP_BIT(Y_AXIS));
      if(st.step_outbits & (1<<STEP_BIT(Z_AXIS))) STEP_PORT |= (1<<STEP_BIT(Z_AXIS)); else STEP_PORT &= ~(1<<STEP_BIT(Z_AXIS));
```


According to the Compiler Explorer at godbolt.org, this produces something like this:

```
sbrs r24,3
  rjmp .L2
  sbi 34-0x20,3
  rjmp .L3
.L2:
  cbi 34-0x20,3
```
  
... which shouldn't clobber any bits.

FWIW, I am working to patch my fork of grbl-mega to address this.

title: sys.state: bit map or enumeration?
body:
In most places in the codebase, sys.state seems to be treated as an informal enumeration. However, occasionally something like this pops up:

if ((sys.state & (STATE_CYCLE | STATE_HOMING | STATE_JOG)) ||

... where individual bits are being tested. Also, the values are defined as bit() values in system.h.

What's the cannonical approach to sys.state supposed to be? Can I assume that only one bit can ever be set in sys.state? Or should I assume that any possible combination of bits could occur?

title: Homing Issues
body:
I have built a basic cnc running nema 23s and tb 6560 steppers controlled with grbl 0.9.
The limit switches are NC on a 24v circuit running to relays that connect to the 5v circuit of the arduino (also NC).
Having issues where the machine randomly errors (Error: Homing Fail) as it hits the switches, everytime it errors on a different axis and we have no idea what is going on. It used to work with seperate 2 core speaker wire for the switches running to the relays but I originally bought 6 core so I have joined the switches so that both the stepper motor wires and the switch wires are running parallel, yes I know this is a recipe for disaster in terms of interference but thats what it had before when the speaker wire was taped to the outside of the 6 core so nothing has changed, also it is running on 24v so shouldnt have interference issues?
The thing we have just tried to do is build an RC filter on the 5v side which hasn't done anything at all. With or without the filter there is a definite drop between 5v and 0v on the limit pins so not sure as to why it keeps erroring out?

title: How program the boot loader and program grbl on CAMTOOL 3.3v
body:
I am posting my findings as i hope this is helpful and presents a straight forward method of updating this board when all else fails. 
This are the document i used to draw my conclusion and produce my method.
https://www.instructables.com/id/Arduino-Leonardo-as-Isp/
http://wiki.sainsmart.com/index.php/101-60-280
http://s3.amazonaws.com/s3.image.smart/download/101-60-280/Schematic_CAMTOOL%20CNC-V3.3.pdf
I turned (or put out of circuit) r19 as this put 220 ohms to ground. R19 ran through a circuit to control an opto-coupler, thus the pin was too grounded to produce high signals on the line. With out MISO programming gets messy. So I am taking r19 out of the circuit for programming and then putting it back in to run the unit. I believe this stopped my programming originally. c46 was also turned to the side (or taken out of circuit). But i don't think it is necessary to take out in order to get the leanardo to program the camtool processor. I solder programming wires for MISO and MOSI directly to the micro controller. I put a pin header on the other end so i could connect them to the lenardo for programming the bootloader and the grbl software..

title: grbl use with MKS BASE 1.6 board
body:
I am using grbl on the MKS BASE 1.6 board.  It is basically an arduino mega combined with a RAMPS 1.4 on a single board.  Currently available for around $30 (with 5 A4982 drivers installed), so its pretty attractive.

The first problem I encountered was that the microstepping settings were different for the various axis.  On the RAMPS 1.4 board these settings are controlled via jumpers.  On the MKS BASE board, the MS1 and MS2 pins on the A4982 drivers are routed to pins on the atmega mpu:
             
X     MS1     PE2 (4)
       MS2     PH3 (15)
Y     MS1     PF5 (92)
       MS2     PF4 (93)
Z     MS1     PA0 (78)
       MS2     PG2 (70)
E0   MS1     PK1 (88)
       MS2     PK2 (87)
E1   MS1     PF3 (94)
       MS2     PG5 (1)  

As far as I can tell, these pins are not initialized anywhere in the grbl code.  Its not reasonable to expect grbl to account for every variation of board in the world.  I've added some code to steppers.c to initialize these pins as outputs and set them to the correct state during the rest of the stepper initialization.  

However, this doesn't seem like a very sustainable solution, as I'd like to be able to easily take updates as they become available.  I know that I can add custom board definitions to the various .h files, but where should I locate board-specific code?  

The second issue isn't really an issue, just a note for others who might be struggling with the problem.  The MKS BASE 1.6 board has limit switch inputs for both min and max limits for x, y, and z axis.  However, grbl reports only a single pin state variable for each axis.  If you define the limit switches to be active high (a positive voltage on the limit pin indicates that that limit switch has been activated), any unconnected limit switch inputs can mask the connected input.

As an example, I have a X- (minimum) limit switch, but no X+ limit switch.  Since grbl reports only one pin state for X axis limit switches, it always reports "active" for the X axis, regardless of the state of the X- limit switch.  

The solution to this is simple, I just added a jumper between the limit pin and ground (conveniently located next to each other on the board I am using) for each limit switch input I am not using.

GRBL is an outstanding project, I've been using it since the early releases!

Steve

title: Pause command (!) doen't stop 3D printer while moving with Python
body:
I'm controlling my 3D printer as a positioning table using Python
I can send any coordinates as follows: 
s = serial.Serial('COM11',115200) # COM, baudrate
s.write(b'G01 X10')

I want to stop its movement while the printer is still moving by pressing the pause button on the keyboard, as an emergency button.
So have tried using
s.write(b'!')
s.write(b'0x18')
s.write(b'M226')

But my printer doesn't stop moving. It always finishes its previous command and only then listens.

I've tried using Repertier host software to send G Codes like: !  M226 and 0x18
But there it's the same problem.
Am I forgetting something or is it just not possible to stop a movement?

Printer: Creality 3D CR-10 mini 3D printer

I'm wondering whether there is a setting anywhere so that GRBL finishes the current line of Gcode it has been sent before replying with "ok\r\n". title: Ideal pin to use for plasma control relay GRBL 1.1 and greater
body:
We are making a versatile hardware controller that will make it easy to connect spindle, laser or plasma. we've got a transistor output for spindle and laser control, that's fine.

What we are trying to do is feed relay contacts to switch the plasma on and off. with our custom board the relay will be bound to it's respective pin permanently without user interaction. 

The question is, should we bind the relay to Spindle enable, Spindle direction or Spindle PWM.

Obviously we don't want the relay to chatter during normal spindle or laser operation. We were thinking of adding an ATTiny to receive the pwm signal on spindle PWM pin (If any) and then create a solid 5V output. Although we were hoping to avoid this.

We will have independent screw terminals for Spindle, PWM laser and Plasma on the custom board.

So, What do you think the best option would be to eliminate the need to change any hardware and be able to control spindle, laser or plasma.

title: Noisy spindle after upgrading to grbl 1.1
body:

after upgrading my woodpecker grbl0.9 controller (it has no version printed on it, i assume version 1) to current grbl1.1  i have noticed a quite loud beeping noise when spindle is on, especially at lower speed values (50/1000 .. 200/1000).
The power of spindle is also reduced.
Because i had changed not only the grbl version (limit switches added, cabling changed, ...),
i have "downgraded" the grbl version back to the original version provided by manufacturer. It reports as grbl0.9j. And the noise was gone (same hardware, different firmware).

title: Question: Homing ends at outer limit of max travel range
body:
Hi,

I have set the maximum travel range to 5000 (directly within defaults.h). Now when I do a homing with X-axis and $23 set to 0, after completion the X-axis ends at position -1.0 (which is correct because pull-off distance is at 1).

But when I do homing with the Y-axis in next step with $23 set to 2 (means inverted movement direction for Y-axis) after homing sequence has completed, this axis is located at -4999.0 - means the pull-off-distance has been calculated from outer limit and not from centre position at 0.0.

What could be the reason for this? What am I doing wrong?

Thanks!

title: GRBL stalls with "Bf:14,0"
body:
Working with the most recent version from GIT I stumble upon a strange problem. I'm quite sure I'm doing something wrong but have no clue what it could be. I stream my G-code to GRBL and check regularly the buffer fill level by sending a "?" and evaluating the result in order to avoid overflows. Then my code ensures the command queue never becomes full. But at some point I get back a

Bf:14,0

which means one command is in queue and the serial buffer is filled up completely. Amazingly at this point the serial buffer is not processed any more, no matter what I do I do not get rid of this state and have to restart my hardware.

So...any idea what could cause the serial buffer to lock when it is filled completely?

Regarding my environment: I neither use a standard Arduino nor a GUI, I'm streaming the data via a direct serial connection to the MCU using an own application.

Thanks!

title: Inconsistent behavior between job when switching laser mode
body:
In relation to issue #406 and while writing a post-processor that will automatically engage/disengage GRBL's laser mode, I ran into what may be a bug. The code below:

sends the $32=1 command to engage the laser mode
moves the head to a safe height
moves the head to a starting position
moves the head to a cutting height
moves the head in a rectangular pattern
moves the head to a safe height and position
sends the $32=0 command to disengage laser mode.

If the program is sent again immediately to repeat the job, it will not start and or finish the job properly and the fault is inconsistent in where the program ends. Sending GRBL a soft reset after this will clear the inconsistency and allow the job to run again. No error is reported or sent back from GRBL indicating that it ran into trouble. Running the code through the GRBL-sim also indicates no issues in the code itself (i.e. no invalid G or M code lines).

Without the $32 commands the code executed repeatably and without issue.


(1001)
G90 G94
G17
G21
;G43.1 Z0
(Enable the laser mode!)
(Using X offset: 0)
(Using Y offset: 0)
(Using Z offset: 0)
$32=1
G28 G91 Z0
G90

(2D Contour5)
S12000 M4
G54
G0 X350.6 Y152.4
Z15
Z0
G1 Z-0.2 F333.3
Y261.462 F5000
G3 X345.6 Y266.462 I-5
G1 X60.8
G3 X55.8 Y261.462 J-5
G1 Y43.338
G3 X60.8 Y38.338 I5
G1 X345.6
G3 X350.6 Y43.338 J5
G1 Y152.4
G0 Z0
G28 G91 Z0
G90
G28 G91 X0 Y0
G90
M5
;G49
(Disable the laser mode!)
$32=0

title: Possible Bug: M3 starts laser when idle and when laser mode is on ($32=1)
body:
I am using grbl 1.1f on genuine Arduino Uno. I am using CNC for milling and laser operation. Spindle is not controlled via grbl, only laser is. 
I am making a pendant that controls gcode sender and sends gcode commands to the computer. 
I was looking into a command that turns on laser at weakest power when laser mode is on $32=1 and idle, just to see it's position more accurately. I am able to do this when laser mode is off ($32=0) and I use "M4 S1" to do this. 

However laser mode ($32=1) only enables laser when moving: G1, G2 or G3 (https://github.com/gnea/grbl/wiki/Grbl-v1.1-Laser-Mode). So M3 or M4 Sxxx doesn't turn it on when idle. So this works as it should.

Ok here it comes. There is a certain scenario that overcomes this automatic safety switch that enables to turn on laser with M3 when cnc is idle.
Commands i used are as follows:

M4 S1
G1 G91 X0.1 F5000
G1 G91 X-0.1 F5000
M5

Now this is when laser is off, and only turns on when G1 command is moving a CNC. Let's continue.

M3

M3 turns it on now, this time also when idle, even though it should not. It works every time for me. But after jogging a bit it doesn't do this anymore (not always). M5 turns it off, and M3 on again. 
I don't think that exactly G1 G91 X0.1 F5000 is at fault, only G1 and then whatever does it. Haven't tested for G2 or G3.

I believe it is a bug, for safety reasons it should not be acting in such way. I am exploiting this bug for laser test fire at weakest power - but would rather have a dedicated gcode command that would fire laser at weakest power.

tldr: when $32=1, M3 turns laser on when idle after G1 command. Would be awesome to have laser test fire.

title: Limit switches trigger on RPi and not on laptop
body:
I have a very strange problem. I have Arduino Uno (original) connected to the Raspberry pi and running UGS (universal gcode sender) on it. Grbl version is 1.1g.
Hardware wise I have limit switches (normally closed) connected to Arduino. I have low pass filters with operation amplifier on it. It is set so, that when limit is triggered the op amp sends 5V to Arduino, if limits are not triggered, it sends 0V. Before the signal goes to op amp it is filtered with low pass filter, as described in grbl wiki.
Recently I also changed all cables for limit switches. I used UTP cat 6 (twisted pairs with shielding connected to earth) to further reduce interference. Shielded cable is from switches to filter and then again from filter to Arduino. So the signal should not get interfered in the last few centimetres.

However I can't seem to get rid of random limit switch triggering when running from RPi. But if I connect Arduino to my laptop (MacBook) the limits don't randomly trigger when jogging - when motors move - anymore. I tried to reduce motors acceleration but it helped so little it's not worth bothering.
Arduino is powered from USB, RPi is powered from 50W 5V industrial power supply. Op amp is powered directly from the same power supply.

tldr: I don't know why limits trigger only when running from Raspberry pi and work ok when running from laptop.

I would be grateful for your ideas.
Aleš

title: After homing machine, G28 triggers limit switch
body:
I have an [XYZ-Carve](http://xyzcarve.3dtek.xyz/), which is similar to the XCarve. I use the [UGS Platform](https://winder.github.io/ugs_website/) software to send G-code to the machine.
When using the G28 command to go back to zero, the tool travels all the way along the Z axis and hits the limit switch.


I have set the firmware settings to the following:

```
Max travel (mm):
  X: 1000
  Y: 1000
  Z: 200
Homing pull-off: 1 mm
```

The X & Y limit switches are at the bottom left of the machine, and Z is at the top.


After homing, UGS displays the following position (mm, first number is work pos, second number is absolute machine pos):
```
  X:  0.00      -999.00
  Y:  0.00      -999.00
  Z:  199.00    -1.00
```
I read somewhere that the negative co-ordinates are normal for CNCs, so although it seems odd to me, I am not concerned about that.


Issuing the following command,
```
  G90 G0 X0 Y0
  G90 G0 Z0
```
takes the machine to
```
  X:  0.00     -999.00
  Y:  0.00     -999.00
  Z:  0.00     -200.00
```
which is bottom left of X/Y axis and Z all the way down.

And the following,
```
G91 G28 X0 Y0
```

takes it out to
```
  X:  999.00     0.00
  Y:  999.00     0.00
```

However, when moving the Z axis to zero,
```
  G91 G28 Z0
```

it hits the limit switch and triggers an alarm and immediately stops.
This is because it thinks that Z 0 is right on the limit, instead of being just shy of hitting it.

I imagine the correct thing for the machine to do after homing is to set machine Z to 0 instead of -1. Hence, the zero position is where the tool stops after homing (which is 1 mm away from the limit switch).


Please tell me if this is a bug in the grbl code, a problem with the XYZ-Carve, or have I just done something wrong?

title: GRBL for ATXMega?
body:
This is more a feature request than an issue:

On a standard Arduino with 16 MHz clock GRBL provides a maximum step frequency of about 30 kHz, when one replaces the Oscillator by a 20 MHz variant, the limit is somewhere at 37 kHz. Meanwhile this is beyond the lower limit also for hobbyists and DIY-projects.

One easy solution which would come into my mind: use an ATXMega with 40 MHz clock would boost the maximum step frequency to about 75 kHz which is far beyond other CNC controllers but an easy to do improvement.

I already tried to compile GRBL for an ATXMega, but it seems all register names are different there, so some more work would have to be done which is beyond my knowledge.

So perhaps anybody can implement ATXMega support simply by replacing the register calls/names and encapsulate everything in some #ifdefs, so that it still can be compiled for "normal" ATMegas too? This would be a quick and _not_ dirty solution which boosts the performance of GRBL.

title: 5 lines of gcode reproducibly crashes GRBL 1.1
body:
Hi, following 5 lines of g-code (part of a much larger file) reproducibly crashes GRBL 1.1f (grbl_v1.1f.20170801.hex) :

```
S5000 M3
G0 X61.569 Y16.0
G1 X41.583 Y18.051 F170
G1 X41.646 Y18.058
G1 X41.672 Y18.059
G1 X44.451
G1 Z2.0
G0 X28.358 Y3.559
M5
```

with following settings:
```
$0=10
$1=255
$2=0
$3=1
$4=0
$5=0
$6=0
$10=1
$11=0.010
$12=0.002
$13=0
$20=0
$21=0
$22=0
$23=0
$24=25.000
$25=500.000
$26=250
$27=1.000
$30=1000
$31=0

$112=375.000

$122=15.000
$130=200.000
$131=200.000
$132=200.000
```

Tested on latest and stable versions of bCNC and UGS. GRBL answers with some interesting >127 ascii characters and at the end is:
`787|FS:0.0,0|Pn:P|Ov:100,100,100|A:S`

After spending a day making a scrap material, I flashed a 'fresh new' bare atmega328p (with just 16MHz crystal) with latest HEX and connected with FTDI cable, the same error showed again!

Later I found, that lowering steps/mm down to 6000 helps.... I'm using DRV8825 with 1/32-step, which runs motor really smoothly so going down to 1/16 (and 3200 steps/mm) really unfortunate.

I don't think, this is the limit of microcontroller - issue is there  even when this g-code is run on 25% feed rate! On some feed rates like 25% - the crash behaves quite dangerously - X-axis keeps running!

title: Homing cycle.
body:
have $27.
Also
#define HOMING_CYCLE_0 ((1 << X_AXIS) | (1 << Y_AXIS))

title: Parsing incoming messages from GRBL
body:
I was wondering if some kind person could write a basic parse routine for me to run on another Arduino which would sniff the data from the PC/Grbl communication Link,  By using a second arduino i can receive the return messages from the grbl TX pin - This is not affecting the operation of the pc/grbl control.
Im currently able to read the return string and output it via the arduino IDE serial monitor.

I would like to be able to parse the data into an array (block) so i can manipulate the values returned for Spindle speed and the operation of suds/coolant pump and the spindle direction.  I am attempting to make an interface between grbl and my milling machine motors variable frequency drive.  To cut a long story short - the high frequency noise from the VFD upsets the grbl operation, im wanting to transmit the commands over RS485 between the board sniffing the signals and the VFD.  The return message has the beauty of telling me when a function has been performed and not when its being queued which is what i would get from the other side of the comms link. 
Being able to do this would also benefit those wishing to build a torch height controller for a plasma table or any other project where reporting would be an advantage as its not possible to provide any further resources from grbl to transmit from a second serial port due to the maxed out memory especially on the UNO variant.

 I can see its possible and have the ability to do everything apart from parsing the message string,  any help would be most appreciated.

title: Spindle Enable Stays High
body:
I've done a lot of searching on this and other forums but can't seem to track down my answer.

I'm using a generic CNC shield atop a generic UNO loaded with GRBL 1.1, with bCNC on a raspberry pi functioning as the host.

Under default settings, with variable spindle enabled, the voltage at the Spindle Enable pin stays at 5v no matter what I do. If I disable the variable spindle, spindle enable now works like it's supposed to, but I can't take advantage of the TTL functionality of the laser diode.  The laser that I'm using is an Eleksmaker LA03-3500 3.5W laser with TTL. I have the Power +/- connected to a 12v p/s and connecting the TTL wires to spindle enable (again, with variable spindle disabled) is the only way I can get any use out of it.

I know that disabling the spindle causes pins 11 and 12 on the UNO to swap, so my first thought was to swap the TTL to the Z-limit pins and enable the variable spindle, but those pins output 0v no matter what I'm doing with the spindle in bCNC. I've tried changing the max spindle rpm to 255, but it doesn't seem to change anything. I've also tried messing with the USE_SPINDLE_DIR_AS_ENABLE_PIN settings in the grbl firmware but it also doesn't change anything. The spindle enable pin always reads 5v unless I disable the variable spindle.

Is there something I'm doing wrong? Is there a setting, either in the grbl firmware or in the bCNC config that I'm overlooking? I assume that since my laser diode has TTL functionality, and it's something that's supported in grbl 1.1, it should work, no?

I've learned a lot from my research and have been able to systematically solve all the problems I've encountered thus far, but this one has got me stumped. I would really like to be able to do grayscale engraving with this machine, but without the TTL that's not possible right?

Thanks for any help you guys can offer on this matter, I really appreciate it.

title: Plasma cutter touch-off cycle
body:
I have built a CNC plasma cutter from scratch using GRBL, and an arduino.

I'm using Universal G-Code Sender to control the GRBL, and one of the features that I thought I could get away with not having before, is really starting to become an issue.

Many CNC plasma cutters, in order to control the height of the torch above the work piece will run a touch-off subroutine. This compensates for a lot of the warping/shifting due to heat application.

The following is an excerpt from my code:

`N0120 Z3.2`
`N0130 F100 G38.2 Z-10`
`N0140 F20 G38.4 Z10`
`N0150 G92 Z0`
`N0160 F50 Z3.20`
`N0170 M03`

From my understanding:

F100 (feed speed) G38.2 (probe toward work piece stop on contact) Z-10 (direction towards work piece, and a point to stop and error if no contact is met)

This piece of code seems to work. It probes down, and stops when the torch contacts, and the switch is tripped.

Then the next line is supposed to withdraw the probe, and stop on loss of contact (G38.4). It does, but as soon as the contact is lost, it throws a "ALARM: Probe Error"

Ideally, as soon as it stops, I want it to move onto the G92, which is setting the Z height of the top of the plate at 0, then moving up to my 3.2mm cut height before firing the torch and starting with the cut.


So I think I've localised my problem to the G38.4 command, but I don't understand why it doesn't work, as the 38.2 seems to work fine. 

Any advice? I know this may not be a strictly GRBL problem, but you guys seem to know the most about the finiky bits of G-Code and how grbl is interpreting the commands.

Or.. am I going about this all the wrong way?

title: Re-enable Interrupts after setting/resetting Exec-State-Flag?
body:
Not sure where to ask this since there does not seem to be a forum or mailing list:

When sending e.g. a command "?" GRBL-internal a flag EXEC_STATUS_REPORT is set using function system_set_exec_state_flag() and later after it has been processed this flag is reset by calling system_clear_exec_state_flag(). Both functions disable the interrupts globally by calling cli() but I can't see where/when these interrupts are re-enabled.

So my questions: where are the interrupts re-enabled?

And doesn't this cause communication interruptions when new commands arrive as long as the IRQs are disabled?

title: GRBL crash/flood with illegal responses also when doing command-handshake
body:
Since the related issue was closed and I see no possibility to reopen it, I have to create a new one:

Randomly I notice a behaviour which looks like some kind of crash for me: after some time, GRBL does not send back a valid response any longer but floods my client application by sending huge amounts of ASCII-character "4" - until I do an hard reset (Ctrl-X does not work in this case)

I'm working with main trunk head from GIT on a standard ArduinoNano. I'm sending commands like

$110=somevalue\n
$120=somevalue\n
$111=somevalue\n
$121=somevalue\n
G0X20.000Y30.000\n
?

where I wait for the corresponding "ok" after every "$"-command was sent to ensure proper writing of EEPROM without any IRQ issues. 

Now this crash happens by factor 10 more seldom, but it still happens.

I do not need these data to be written into EEPROM, since I send them down to the Arduino every time I start the application. So as workaround for this problem, is there a way to disable EEPROM-writing and to keep these values in RAM instead?

As mentioned, beside the handhsake I always keep care of GRBLs buffer, so in no case more than 128 bytes are sent and in no case the commands are sent too fast to have an buffer overflow.

I also tried to work at lower baud rates (recompiled GRBL for that) but this does not make a difference.
