title: GRBL crash/flood with illegal responses
body:
Randomly I notice a behaviour which looks like some kind of crash for me: after some time, GRBL does not send back a valid response any longer but floods my client application by sending huge amounts of ASCII-character "4" - until I do an hard reset (Ctrl-X does not work in this case)

I'm working with main trunk head from GIT on a standard ArduinoNano. What I guess at the moment what causes these problems: it seems to depend on my method of sending commands to GRBL. So instead of sending e.g.

$110=somevalue\n
$120=somevalue\n
$111=somevalue\n
$121=somevalue\n
G0X20.000Y30.000\n
?

with each line sent separately, I submit something like

$110=somevalue\n$120=somevalue\n$111=somevalue\n$121=somevalue\nG0X20.000Y30.000\n?

with all commands sent at once. Here I always keep care of GRBLs buffer, so in no case more than 128 bytes are sent and in no case the commands are sent too fast to have an buffer overflow.

I also tried to work at lower baud rates (recompiled GRBL for that) but this does not make a difference.

What could be the reason for this? Isn't the code from GIT a stable version? Or is it a problem in UART receiving of GRBL which can't handle data when they are sent too fast?

title: Enhancement -  Disable Z axis so homing works when there are only two axis in use.
body:
As I am new to GRBL as I want to use a laser etcher for making circuit boards.  I have a Chinese laser and using a Mega as a controller.  I installed limit switches for safety but when I tried to enable homing, I keep getting errors because there is no Z axis.

I have read some lists that recommend installing a switch to manually fake a limit switch engaging.  I think it would be better if there was a way to ignore the Z axis if there is no Z motor using some flag or modify the homing $22=X  where X is a different mode.

1 - Normal XYZ axis
2 - 2 Axis XY

This may be useful for future when GRBL is capable of handling more axis.

title: Probing error ALARM:PROBE
body:
Hi,

I try to solve this problem now for one and a half days. I designed my own CNC machine and homeing it is no problem. But when I start the **UGS** it gives me an ```ALARM:PROBE``` but my Probe is not probing nor touching anything to close a circuit. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18379852/43183276-d4fa4fe6-8fe4-11e8-9971-fe3f67e92b11.png)

When I start probing (after homing, repositioning to my workpice and putting the axes to 0) I get a bunch of errors. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18379852/43183422-61e3de86-8fe5-11e8-91ea-2f6d295f8840.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18379852/43183548-ccf514ba-8fe5-11e8-869b-2fb4f5ed185a.png)

I tried different versions of UGS, tried to invert the probe pin. A pull down resistor is not needed (I read it in several forums but maybe I am mistaken?). I am followed this [tutorial](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kpz-6x_synE).

I use an STM103 ([source code](https://github.com/usbcnc/grbl))  and no Arduino as a controller for grbl. When I put the Probing pin to Ground the error goes away and I can start probing. 

Here are my settings:

```
$0 = 64    (Step pulse time, microseconds)
$1 = 0    (Step idle delay, milliseconds)
$2 = 7    (Step pulse invert, mask)
$3 = 7    (Step direction invert, mask)
$4 = 0    (Invert step enable pin, boolean)
$5 = 0    (Invert limit pins, boolean)
$6 = 0    (Invert probe pin, boolean)
$10 = 0    (Status report options, mask)
$11 = 0.010    (Junction deviation, millimeters)
$12 = 0.002    (Arc tolerance, millimeters)
$13 = 0    (Report in inches, boolean)
$20 = 0    (Soft limits enable, boolean)
$21 = 1    (Hard limits enable, boolean)
$22 = 1    (Homing cycle enable, boolean)
$23 = 0    (Homing direction invert, mask)
$24 = 25.000    (Homing locate feed rate, mm/min)
$25 = 500.000    (Homing search seek rate, mm/min)
$26 = 250    (Homing switch debounce delay, milliseconds)
$27 = 4.000    (Homing switch pull-off distance, millimeters)
$30 = 10    (Maximum spindle speed, RPM)
$31 = 0    (Minimum spindle speed, RPM)
$32 = 0    (Laser-mode enable, boolean)
$100 = 640.000    (X-axis travel resolution, step/mm)
$101 = 640.000    (Y-axis travel resolution, step/mm)
$102 = 640.000    (Z-axis travel resolution, step/mm)
$110 = 600.000    (X-axis maximum rate, mm/min)
$111 = 600.000    (Y-axis maximum rate, mm/min)
$112 = 600.000    (Z-axis maximum rate, mm/min)
$120 = 40.000    (X-axis acceleration, mm/sec^2)
$121 = 40.000    (Y-axis acceleration, mm/sec^2)
$122 = 40.000    (Z-axis acceleration, mm/sec^2)
$130 = 250.000    (X-axis maximum travel, millimeters)
$131 = 150.000    (Y-axis maximum travel, millimeters)
$132 = 90.000    (Z-axis maximum travel, millimeters)
```

MANY Thanks and have a nice day.

title: Weird glitches with movement accuracy
body:
I have a pretty big MPCNC based laser engraver/cutter with GRBL 1.1f (custom built for disabling Z axis homing). But I have an issue with movement accuracy, not straight lines, and shifts. 
![img_1509](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/184043/42726609-eaf83f4e-879f-11e8-81a6-dd0fcb0972c0.jpg)
I've eliminated skipped steps as the cause, kind of. There is no binding in kinematics, no indicative sound. And this is 100% repeatable, I did run the same G code several times in a row without moving a material - 100% match. I think, skipped steps have to be sporadic or at least slightly deviating.
I've seen mentions of driver's temperature cutoffs as a possible cause. Indeed, drivers were pretty hot, but reducing current and adding active cooling (till heatsinks are barely noticeable warm) didn't solve the issue.
I've tried to reduce a feed rate down to 300mm/min without any difference, still 100% the same result.
Offsetting a drawing to another part of the work area (to ensure that this is not kinematics binding) showed exactly the same defects.

I'm frustrated. Any ideas? What diagnostic steps I've missed?

P.S. I've attached example drawing and G code.
https://www.dropbox.com/s/3r71mmzgqvi6fq0/Dimond_test.svg?dl=0
https://www.dropbox.com/s/gnbschb8eyzmwh6/dimond_test2a.gcode?dl=0

title: grbl via bluetooth hc-05 speed problem

Hi everybody.

I made a connection to cnc through two modules hc-05 (master-> slave)
But there was a problem of the sneakiness of the transfer

the transmission speed via bluetooth is not more than 9600 approximately
settings are all set correctly hc 05 is set to 38400
(other values ​​of the data transfer rate also do not matter)

I found an article that is similar to my problem
https://forum.arduino.cc/index.php?topic=424791.15

   > "You are encountering the age old problem of latency. A synchronous packet system cannot send each of your asynchronous bytes without imbedding them in a packet"

what can i do to low down latency.
or use another module?

title: Issue with turning off mist and flood coolant
body:
Working on my GUI and I found that when both mist and flood coolant are enabled and both turned on, they cannot be turned off until both a 0xA0 and a 0xA1 are issued. Also, if the sending of the 0xA0 and 0xA1 commands aren't done right they are ineffective. If turning mist or flood on individually without the other turned on everything works fine. The problem occurs when both are turned on at the same time. 
Note:  I didn't have my meter handy, so I can't say if this is just the reporting and the pins are functioning correctly, or if if the pins are also not toggling.

Here is a run of status reports with inserts where the toggles were sent to show the problem and some notes.

### First section shows that using flood and mist individually works as expected

<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
>>>> 0xA1 (Mist toggle) sent
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|Ov:100,100,100|A:M>			Mist on
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|WCO:2.000,2.000,0.000>
>>>> 0xA1 (Mist toggle) sent
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|Ov:100,100,100>				Mist off (no problem as long as flood isn't also on)
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|WCO:2.000,2.000,0.000>
>>>> 0xA0 (Flood toggle) sent
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|Ov:100,100,100|A:F>			Flood on
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
>>>> 0xA0 (Flood toggle) sent
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|Ov:100,100,100>				Flood off (no problem as long as mist isn't also on

### This next section shows the problem

<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
>>>> 0xA1 (Mist toggle) sent
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|Ov:100,100,100|A:M>				Mist turned on (No problem so far)
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|WCO:2.000,2.000,0.000>
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0>

<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|Ov:100,100,100|A:M>
>>>> 0xA0 (Flood toggle) sent
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|Ov:100,100,100|A:FM>			Flood and mist both turned on (Again, no problem so far)
<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|WCO:2.000,2.000,0.000>

title: Ading GRBL library to Arduino IDE for compiling GRBL
body:
When i follow these instruction (IDE version 1.8.5) for adding the GRBL library to the arduino IDE

"**_IMPORTANT: Select the grbl folder inside the grbl-XXX folder, which only contains the source files and an example directory_**"

I get an error message "**_A subfolder of your sketchbook is not a valid library_**", the library is not added and I can not compile GRBL. When I make a zip file of this folder, the (zip) library is added without errors and I can compile GRBL.

title: Override question. Not necessarily a bug
body:
I finally have a chance to do some work updating my GUI and had a question. It may or may not be a bug.

So lets say you have a programmed feed rate of 100 mm/min and set the feed override at 80%. In this case, Grbl reports the feed rate as 80 mm/min.

Now lets say you have the spindle speed programmed at 1000 rpm and the spindle override at 80%.  Grbl still reports the spindle speed as 1000 rpm. I would have expected it to report 800 rpm.  Is this a bug or is it intentional?

title: Fix Issue #468: Failure to restore mist output (M7) after door open event and cycle start
body:
Fix apparent error in restore masking from protocol module that causes the call to coolant_set_state to not re-enable the mist (M7) output if it was previously enabled.

[Reported issue 468](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/issues/468)

title: Failure to restore mist output (M7) after door open event and cycle start
body:
**Build:** 1.1f (exists since 1.1e)
**Required build configuration:**
```
#define ENABLE_SAFETY_DOOR_INPUT_PIN
#define` ENABLE_M7
```
**Problem description:** If M7 is active (set by gcode or override) and the door open even occurs both the mist (M7) and flood (M8) outputs are cleared. Once door event has cleared and the cycle start input is cycled the job continues but the mist output is not set although the flood is restored if set.

**Notes:** 
 - This is a regression from previous version such as 1.0c when the restore masking was added to the coolant_set_state argument in [protocol.c line 683](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/blob/master/grbl/protocol.c#L683).
 - A [pull request](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/pull/469) has been created with the mask fixed to include mist.

title: It it possible that grbl could report which hard limit was triggered?
body:
Looking at the [alarm codes csv file](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/blob/master/doc/csv/alarm_codes_en_US.csv), it seems as if any hard limit triggered is simply alarm code "1". Since grbl uses different pins for different axis limit switches, could we not have an alarm code that corresponds to the axis triggered? 

10 = x axis alarm
11 = y axis alarm
12 = z axis alarm

Not knowing which axis triggered makes resolving issues such as interference from steppers more difficult to debug. EG: Is it only one axis' limit that consistently triggers erroneously? If so, maybe the switch is bad. If all of my limit switches trigger erroneously then I probably have a problem with my wiring and need to consider was to resolve that.

title: Steps/mm at correct setting causes stepper drive error
body:
There's a chance that this could be a bCNC issue but I thought I'd see if anyone here has any ideas.

In the last few months, I've built two cnc control systems with raspberry pi3/Protoneer boards/grbl1.1 and I'm trying to get one of them tuned to the machine, but not having much luck. This system is for a 5'x10' "lightning cnc" plasma table at a friend's business.

I'm ready to install the computer and all I need to finish is motor tuning. I'm having an issue with the necessarily low steps/mm settings though.   When the steps/mm is set correctly, the motors barely move, then stop randomly and grbl seems to give up, or think the job is done.  Then it needs reset a few times before it responds again.

The x axis steppers have 15t, 4mm pitch rack and pinion setups. At 1/4 microstepping, 200 steps per revolution, and 60mm per revolution, my x axis steps per mm setting should be 13.333. I've checked this a bunch of times and am 99% sure it's right.  I somehow hope that I'm wrong though.

When I set the steps/mm to what it needs to be, no matter what I set the acceleration and max travel speeds to, the motors barely move, and give up way before reaching their requested destination, but grbl doesn't throw any errors and just acts like it accomplished the goal. I also find that trying to jog it hangs up grbl randomly, requiring a soft reset to regain responsiveness. If I put the steps per mm up in the 300+ range, I get smooth running motors but still can't get over 500mm/min rapids, regardless of max travel settings.  (The steppers aren't installed on the machine btw.  I'm tracking RPM, time, and calculating position.) I also tried changing feed rates in g01 commands in addition to jogging at different multipliers.

The maximum performance I can find seems to be around 500mm/minute, with the external driver step settings set to 1/8 microstepping, steps/mm at 1500, max rate at 500, and accel at 20mm/s^2.

The correct setting in Mach 3 on the old controller, in inches, was 3392.3966 steps per inch, which I arrived at using an online calculator, comparing requested travel to actual travel, then adjusting by putting the actual travel back into the calculator. It was spot on whether I asked it to move an inch or ten feet, like within a few thousandths. If I divide this by 25.4 to convert to steps/mm, I get 133.6. This setting also results in slow/locking up motors and unresponsive max travel settings.

I have the checkbox for inches checked in tools in bcnc and have set setting $13(I think) to report in inches. Does this mean that I need to use steps per inch in config instead of steps per mm? I tried the settings that worked perfectly in Mach3 and the motors sound nice but waaay overshoot the intended destination and still can't get near reaching the 70ipm, or 1778mm/min that I need to cut 1/4" steel plate smoothly.


I should add that the table was easily capable of 200 inches per minute rapids using the Gecko G540 and Mach3 so I'm either dealing with a software issue or a hardware compatibility issue between the Protoneer shield and the TB6600 external drivers. The steppers had no problem throwing the gantry around.

Any input would be greatly appreciated!

title: Global interrupt state assumed in eeprom_put_char function
body:
Hi,
I noticed in the eeprom_put_char function the global interrupts are disabled (line 79) with  a cli() call without preserving the prior state of SREG, and at the end of the function, a call to sei() is made.  This will therefore enable global interrupts, even if they were not enabled in the call to cli() on line 79.

Not sure if this matters, but just thought I'd mention it...

138  // Prescaled, 8-bit Fast PWM mode.
139  **#define SPINDLE_TCCRA_INIT_MASK   ((1<<WGM20) | (1<<WGM21))  // Configures fast PWM mode.**

Is this the normal process or am I doing it wrong?

title: Changing the coordinate system on a laser machine
body:
I have a K40 style laser with its default home & origin set at TopLeft. This is convenient because it's easy to load materials and the cutting strength is best in that corner due to alignment issues.

Nearly all software, however, uses the standard cartesian reference frame (0,0) being BottomLeft. This results in my parts being cut mirrored in the x-axis. Moreover if its something like card stock I also need to mirror the stock on the y-axis so the x-mirroring ends up on the correct side of the paper.

This is very confusing to keep track of. How can I configure grbl to have a BL origin but a TL home without only soft limits?

title: Randomly occuring errors
body:
CAD/CAM: Fusion360
Sender: UGS v1.09 From Laptop
CNC: XCarve
Controller: latest XController using Grbl 1.1 
Router and vacuum are on a 20 Amp circuit. Laptop, controller, and other non-motor items are on a separate 15 Amp circuit so the motors of the router and vacuum shouldn't be an influence.

 Error Code Reference:
- [33] The motion command has an invalid target. G2, G3, and G38.2 generates this error, if the arc is impossible to generate or if the probe target is the current position.
- [35] A G2 or G3 arc, traced with the offset definition, is missing the IJK offset word in the selected plane to trace the arc.


I've encountered numerous errors that ruin my carves and I can't pinpoint what's causing it. I can run a .nc file and it will error out on some commands, stop the script and resend and it will run error free. It's to the point that I can't do a single carve without it messing up on something. I feel like the messages are getting garbled at some point either during transmission or inside the grbl controller. I say this because "G1" commands aren't listed under error 33 but they are triggering that. Also the Error 35 I have is on a command that does work in other instances and it clearly has an "IJK" component.

I've copied the relevant data from UGS into excel files (from start of carve until when I stopped). You can see the exact same set of commands will work one time and error another. I have noticed an odd pattern about these errors. **They only occur near the start of the carve.** This typically ruins the first loop around a multiple depth contour and then the rest of the loops are perfect.

[3) 2F Downcut.txt](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/files/1945319/3.2F.Downcut.txt) (my .nc file)
[error.xlsx](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/files/1945301/error.xlsx)
[worked fine.xlsx](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/files/1945302/worked.fine.xlsx)

You can see in the image below, that at the bottom right, once it reached the beginning of the arc, it didn't perform it and instead shot straight left. This was again repeated at the bottom-left where it went straight up. 
![error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20349377/39223842-c9a6fdce-4809-11e8-81b8-28241637cd29.jpg)


During the same carve, I had another set of errors that when ran another time it ran perfectly fine.

[3) 2F Downcut.txt](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/files/1945372/3.2F.Downcut.txt) (my .nc file)
[error2.xlsx](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/files/1945369/error2.xlsx)
[worked fine_2.xlsx](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/files/1945370/worked.fine_2.xlsx)

The following picture shows a similar event to the first one. It didn't complete the small arc around the corner of the piece therefore cutting short into the material on the first pass. The rest of the passes went as they should have.
![error2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20349377/39224796-9e95dc90-480e-11e8-82ae-413beb659334.jpg)



The last picture from a different carve (no data) is where I've drilled holes and the first time I ran the script in the stock it worked perfect, I then ran the script again on my waste board (mounting holes for double sided piece), the first pass looped backwards and then the rest of the cuts went fine. (Again, errors on the first pass and no other).

![20180414_161820](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20349377/39224296-4175306c-480c-11e8-8090-abec0a1bf65e.jpg)

title: z-axis not responding during homing
body:
I have definitely missed a setting somewhere .
I have at last thrown in the towel and need to admit I cannot find an answer on my own.
I am hoping someone will be kind enough to point this non-programmer in the right direction.
The problem is that when I initiate homing ($H) the spindle moves possibly 2mm in the positive direction ( the correct direction for my application), performs a pull-off motion and then stops. This happens no matter its starting position, meaning it never actuates the z limit switch. 
During the debugging I did try adjusting the travel but it had no effect.
I am running Grbl 1.1 on an Arduino and sending using bCNC.
I have installed limit switches to my cnc build. two switches at the end of each axis ( i.e. Zs, Zn, Ys,Yn and Xs,Xn).  I commented out line 339 ( VARIABLE_SPINDLE) in order to enable d11 and have access to my z-limit switch. I have verified that bCNC sees all of the switches.
I am currently running with default settings, except for the disabled config.h setting. 
any suggestions would be greatly appreciated.
thx

title: Move axes independent from each other
body:
I'm looking for a possibility where all axes move independent from each other and therefore also may stop at different times. So when a motion command is given, they do not "draw" a line from current to target coordinate position, but move to their target positions each at its maximum speed.

In my opinion command G0 should do that, but here the motion speed of axes may be limited in order to let all of them arrive at the same time (so this would be a bug). So there is no real difference between G1 and G0, the last one should let move each axis as fast as possible (which isn't the case), but I also would be happy with a special mode which enables this feature.

title: Inconsistent output of `ok` when machine status is `hold`
body:
I spend a few hours today chasing down response parsing issues associated with getting status reports when grbl is in a variety of states.   There may be some other states that behave similarly (inconsistent), but created output here that demonstrate the issue with `?` when machine state uis **Hold**. 

**Idle**
```
[verbose]GrblFeedbackMessage{message='[GC:G0 G54 G17 G21 G90 G94 M5 M9 T0 F0 S0]', distanceMode='G90', units='G21'}
[GC:G0 G54 G17 G21 G90 G94 M5 M9 T0 F0 S0]
ok
>>> ?
[verbose]<Idle|WPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0|WCO:0.000,0.000,0.000>
ok
```
---
**Run**
```
>>> G91G21G1G93y360f1
ok
>>> ?
[verbose]<Run|WPos:0.000,18.098,0.000|FS:360,0|Ov:100,100,100>
ok
```
**Hold**  
```
`>>> !`
ok
>>> ?
[verbose]<Hold:0|WPos:0.000,50.218,0.000|FS:0,0>
>>> ~
ok
ok
>>> ?
[verbose]<Run|WPos:0.000,57.815,0.000|FS:360,0>
ok
```
So the double OK symbols in sequence at the end are a huge hint as to whats going in.   see below where i ask for multiple reports when machine state is **hold**...  and *then* resume...  where to my suprise i receive the accumulated 'ok's from when the machine was in hold.

_Pic or it didn't happen!_
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8261783/38760286-529ba212-3f2f-11e8-994d-29e9bfc71df5.png)

title: cycle-stop operation? Confusion how to reset after hold.
body:
I might be missing something but i can't find (or sort out how to achieve something analagous to) a cycle-stop command.  Meaning that when a job is running, this action decelerates the machine and skips hold/alert  states, and does to idle.

...Essentially, a 'just stop where you are' action.

per the wiki docs, it appears this functionality is implemented *only* for the **Jog** operation.  It specifically says that it's ignored if the machine state is **Run**

pleas let me know if i just missed it or can achieve this with a sequence of operation (i can wrap a series of operating in my application).

I've tries issuing `~` and can get the machine into a hold state, but if i issue a <ctlr-x> as soft reset.  even though the machine isn't moving, it shift into an alarm state.

homing is not setup in the configuration, so this behavior doesn't seem to jingle with the docs.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8261783/38753475-60b5d5f0-3f13-11e8-8b68-b30f4cc1aab8.png)
i would expect that if the machine is in a hold state, that issuing the soft reset would but nudge the state back into idle.

Any tips greatly appreciate.

title: Laser On-Off Timing
body:
Hello!

I'm working on trying to get my laser cutter to cut accurately in a backwards-and-forwards 'scan line' toolpath in laser mode, similar to the movement in an engraving application. I'm getting some confusing results though. In a test that I've been running, it looks like the laser is turning off too early, and turning on again too early. 

I've attached some photos of the test below. Each line is three consecutive G1 movements, each movement 100mm long, with the spindle powered in M3 mode, cutting from left to right. The cut movements are programmed with an increasing 's' setting (I was looking to see if the behaviour was power dependent), and the non-cutting movement is programmed with an S0 command. The feedrate is 20m/min. The perpendicular lines are etched at 100mm and 200mm as a reference.

![timingtestcut](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5545598/38656595-e93fe9e8-3e5e-11e8-8e1c-bcd421aa7c67.jpg)
![turn-off](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5545598/38656596-e97c069e-3e5e-11e8-8143-55738d229464.jpg)
![turn-on](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5545598/38656597-e9b63508-3e5e-11e8-9e79-f71ba95b3973.jpg)

The spindle setting changes are consistently too early. What is confusing about this is that if the laser tube switching frequency was too low, one would expect the opposite behaviour, ie the cut would (possibly, if the laser had a long decay time) turn off too late and (more likely) turn on again too late. Any insights into what could be causing the behaviour I'm getting in the test?

While I have been working on solving this problem I have been experimenting with SPINDLE_PWM_OFF_VALUE, to see if it changes the performance of the on-off timing. At the moment I can't see that it is causing any difference; neither in the laser cutting performance, laser tube current, or measured with a voltmeter at the spindle PWM pin. (Certainly no improvement to the on-off timing in the test cut). In laser mode ($32=1) with G1 motion mode, M3 constant laser power mode, S0, laser tube current is 0 mA rather than ~5% (~2 mA) that I expected to get (with SPINDLE_PWM_OFF_VALUE 16). Is there something I'm not understanding?

All help warmly received, thanks!

---
**Config**
I have used the fit_nonlinear_spindle.py script to calibrate the laser tube. Calibration curve is below
![lasercalibration](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5545598/38656941-0688fac4-3e61-11e8-9d26-0271307fb577.png)
Linear fit from the script (scaled to have s commands from 0 to 1000)
![line_fit](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5545598/38656967-22715c40-3e61-11e8-9929-c2f5f59c9e3b.png)
Solution from the script (that I put into config.h and cpu_map.h)
>SOLUTION:
>
>[Update these #define values and uncomment]
>[ENABLE_PIECEWISE_LINEAR_SPINDLE in config.h.]
>#define N_PIECES 2
>#define RPM_MAX 1011.6
>#define RPM_MIN 7.2
>#define RPM_POINT12 145.1
>#define RPM_LINE_A1 6.526415e-02
>#define RPM_LINE_B1 -1.553319e+01
>#define RPM_LINE_A2 2.654261e-01
>#define RPM_LINE_B2 1.350105e+01
>
>[To operate over full model range, manually write these]
>['$' settings or alter values in defaults.h. Grbl will]
>[operate between min($30,RPM_MAX) and max($31,RPM_MIN)]
>$30=1011.6 (rpm max)
>$31=7.2 (rpm min)
>
>[Update the following #define values in cpu_map.h]
>#define SPINDLE_PWM_MIN_VALUE 16

I have also set   SPINDLE_PWM_OFF_VALUE to 16.

I'm using grbl 1.1f. My grbl config is 
>$0=10
>$1=255
>$2=0
>$3=3
>$4=0
>$5=0
>$6=0
>$10=1
>$11=0.040
>$12=0.002
>$13=0
>$20=1
>$21=0
>$22=1
>$23=3
>$24=1000.000
>$25=5000.000
>$26=250
>$27=5.000
>$30=1012
>$31=7
>$32=1
>$100=20.810
>$101=20.810
>$102=80.000
>$110=60000.000
>$111=60000.000
>$112=600.000
>$120=2000.000
>$121=2000.000
>$122=300.000
>$130=1400.000
>$131=1000.000
>$132=180.000

title: homing feedback
body:
Feature request.

It would be useful in assessing the repeatability of homing sensors if the homing command return a resume of the changes from the last homing position ( or the turn-on state ). 

This could be returned as a comment to avoid confusing any listening software.

title: homing documentation unclear
body:
https://github.com/gnea/grbl/wiki/Set-up-the-Homing-Cycle

> Homing direction
> 
> The homing directions are controlled by setting $23.
> 
>     Default setting ($23=0), the home location is the top right of your work area, with the spindle all the way up.
>     $23=1 Top left home location.
>     $23=2 Bottom of your work area to be the home location.
>     $23=4 Spindle down home location.
> 

This does not seem to be a clear, unambiguous statement of how this works.  ( how do we get bottom right ? ) 

I'm guessing this is bit encoded LSB encodes 1:left  0:right
bit 1 encodes top / bottom, though  "top" on a horizontal axis is probably not the best word. Top and bottom would make more sense used for Z. 

 $23=4 : presumably this gives top , right, spindle down , so the text does not fully state what this value represents. What is given is 4 examples of the 8 possible states , from which we are supposed to guess the real functionality.   A programmer would probably recognise how this is implemented but this may be unclear or confusing to a non-programmer user. 

It should be fully explicit for any example values given and the underlying bit coded nature should be clearly documented.

title: Closed Loop Support?
body:
The problem with closed loop (that I'm discovering first-hand) is that each axis is independent. The encoder does notice the missed step and compensate for it, but at the expense of time. As you might imagine, not all axes get 'bound up' at the same time - usually just one. This means that one axis is slightly behind on motion while the other two (or three or whatever) continue along their merry way, none the wiser. The result being that the spindle does eventually land in the right position, the path it took to get there may not be as planned. Think about making an XY move where the X axis is a half second behind. The angle of the path will be much different than the expected angle and therefore result in cutting (or not cutting) material that was expected.
Would like to see GRBL support a feedback mechanism with closed loop controllers (like Smart Stepper and MechAduino) so that the encoder can tell the controller to hold up while it corrects its position.
I had thought about hooking the 'error' pin of the closed loop encoder to the feed hold pin, but I don't know if this would quite do what I want (will the feed hold be removed when the error pin reverts?). And I'm not an EE, so I don't really know how to determine what would be required to 'convert' the signals to be compatible.
This feels like it would need to be a 'supported feature' of GRBL to really work properly.

title: Issue on leading zeros in read_float function
body:
All the following G-Code lines :
```
- G0X1
- G0X1.00000000
- G0X000000001
```
are identical. But in Grbl the last one is misunderstood and becomes `G0X0`.
According to G-Code specifications ([http://ws680.nist.gov/publication/get_pdf.cfm?pub_id=823374](http://ws680.nist.gov/publication/get_pdf.cfm?pub_id=823374) p.17) :

_"Notice that initial (before the decimal point and the first non-zero digit) and trailing (after the
decimal point and the last non-zero digit) zeros are allowed but not required. A number written
with initial or trailing zeros will have the same value when it is read as if the extra zeros were not
there."_

Adding leading zero tolerance can be done by inserting in `read_float` function in `nuts_bolts.c:51` the following code :
```
  // Skip leading zeros
  while(c == '0') {
    c = *ptr++;
  }
```

What do you think ?

title: Probing problems
body:
I'm running into issues with auto-leveling on 1.1f. The G38.2 command works fine initially. It moves the probe and lowers it until it makes contact. Once contact is made GRBL no longer responds to commands. When using the auto-leveler in chilipeppr's jgradie workspace the leveling stops. Hitting pause twice makes the commands appear in the console but the CNC does not react. The only thing I can do is to detach the probe, hit pause twice and quickly reattach the probe. I have a feeling that all stepper commands are being blocked when the probe is active. I will in the mean time create some electronics that will send a short pulse on contact (10 ms) instead of maintaining the active 'LOW' state. But it would be nice to have this fixed.

title: checksum algorithm returns boolean instead of byte
body:
Typical use of a boolean operator ('||') where the bitwise operator was meant ('|'). Fortunately there are compiler warnings.
```
grbl/eeprom.c:133:26: warning: '<<' in boolean context, did you mean '<' ? [-Wint-in-bool-context]
     checksum = (checksum << 1) || (checksum >> 7);
                ~~~~~~~~~~^~~~~
grbl/eeprom.c: In function 'memcpy_from_eeprom_with_checksum':
grbl/eeprom.c:144:26: warning: '<<' in boolean context, did you mean '<' ? [-Wint-in-bool-context]
     checksum = (checksum << 1) || (checksum >> 7);
                ~~~~~~~~~~^~~~~
```
Affected are the functions memcpy_to_eeprom_with_checksum() and memcpy_from_eeprom_with_checksum() here:  https://github.com/gnea/grbl/blob/master/grbl/eeprom.c#L130

PS:
To fix this bug we would have to wipe every EEPROM again because otherwise the checksum would be "wrong".

title: Question: Best practice for machine origin after homing
body:
Our machine uses CoreXY. It homes in the top-right of the workspace.
$3=0 & $23=0 yield correct direction of travel for movement and homing.

Upon 'homing' the top-right becomes 0,0 to GRBL. We have been defining a G54 to ensure the 0,0 is located in the bottom-left: G10 L2 P1 X-300 Y-210

During a job, if ctrl-x is issued to immediately 'stop' OR if the movement is 'paused' then stopped, it appears that position is lost and a re-homing is required.

This is contrary to the documentation "If reset while in not motion, position is retained and re-homing is not required."

Is there something we are missing or incorrectly doing with our approach above?
Is there a better way than using WCO to define the 0,0 origin that we would like?

title: Question about planner
body:
Hi, I think only you can help me
how the planner's work? I readed planner.c but not full understand how it works, my question is about coordinated movement
suppose that motor X moves 10 steps and motor Y moves 5 steps, and the maximum velocity is v_max(if v_max is higher velocity is slow, if v_max is less  velocity is high), then motor X moves with v_max and motor Y moves at minor velocity, I calculate it as k= v_max*(motorX/motorY)=v_max*10/5 = v_max*2 then motor Y moves more slow than motor X
and it moves at coordinated movement because motorX/motorY = 10/5 is a natural number, but if motorX/motorY is a rational number(for ex. 1/3) then a phase shift occurs (one of the motor will end before the other) and it's not coordinated movement and it traduce as inertia problem, how can I fix it? I tryed to modify v_max in such way that k= v_max*(motorX/motorY) be a natural number (doing v_max a minimum common multiple of motor X and motor Y ) but, it change the v_max constantly and I be unable to set velocity at desired value, such as 10mm/s as grbl 
best regards

title: coreXY movement direction in GRBL1.1
body:
Just updating from GRBL0.9 to 1.1 and we are having a problem achieving the desired axis direction movements.

Origin is in the bottom left (x=0, y=0)
Desired movement is
Left to right = positive x
Botton to top = positive y

We have tested all $3 combinations as well as changes to motor wiring without being able to achieve the desired directions of movement. When x is correct, y is inverted, and viseversa.

In GRBL0.9, this worked correctly with $3=2.

BTW, we are able to achieve the correct homing direction by setting $23=2. This works as expected.

Any suggestions on what we can try?

title: Trouble with G4 command...... probably
body:
Long story short: theres a problem big problem on "G4 P..." command

Short story long: Hi, I've downloaded, configured and tested the program on my system and everything went perfect with Gcodes from internet, but when I tried with one of my own (inkscape 0.92 made), results that the system stopped before thrusting the mill for quite a while, and time later continued with the operations.

After checking the programs (bCNC 0.9.11 and inkscape 0.92), everything looked normal, so I compared my gcodes generated and downloded and I found something, the internet G-codes doesn't have "G4 P100" before thrusting the mill.

Now if I understand this command should make the cnc wait for 100 microseconds, so I take my chronometer and opened the console of bCNC and surprise, the cnc was waiting for 100 seconds after each "G4 P100" command (that was sent after thrusting the mill).

Maybe Im missconfiguring or understanding something wrong but, theres any way to correct this issue? (other than eliminating each G4 command?)

Here's an example of my Gcode and in bold where my cnc stays waiting 100 seconds.

G1 Z3.0 S0
G1 F200
G1  X28.5063 Y-27.2591
G4 P0 
G1 Z-0.3 S256
**G4 P100**
G1 F10.000000
G3 X28.6779 Y-27.6124 I1.7881 J0.6502

Thanks for your time.

title: GRBL response formats are lack of consistency
body:
Disclaimer: it's not a big deal and working with GRBL is awesome in any other way, but it still bugs me - and bugs me very much, exactly because GRBL is so consistent in any other way.

We have plenty of different type of status/settings/configs/options/parameters, all are unique and definitely required, but the way you can identify and parse them are very different, and sometimes illogical with lots of exceptions. 

Let me summarize the most important ones:

1. StatusReport
_Request-Response_: One realtime command => one line response without 'ok' (perfect!)
_Detection_: Easy. First char is `<`.
_Parsing_: Two levels: split by pipes for the key-value pairs, and split the pairs by `:`. (However that's not true, see the concerns)
_Concerns_: 
- The status itself (as an enum) is an excpetion. Why is there no just a single char of key for this value? Like S:Alarm, or S:Idle. Yes, it's extra memory, but you can get rid of the string status labels, use simple integers (see error and alarm codes, or setting keys). 
- But there is a second level excpetion within the status, because it has sometimes (but not always) a sub-state (Hold:0). Why they are not a specific kind of states? Or why don't we have sub-states (with default 0) for the other states in the name of consistency? If all the states are just ints, you can have plenty of states/substates.
- WCO is a tricky one, because it's kinda an exception here, but WCO is redundant data anyway, because you can get the current coordinate system from the ParserState ($G) and get the offset for that coosys from the GcodeParameters ($#). But okay, it's nice to have, and because of the key-value pair format, you can easily parse the response when the length is dynamic.
- BufferState (Bf), Speed (FS), OverrideValues (Ov): all are exceptions because you have more values for one key. Even worse that they are in specific order. Sometimes we have key-value pairs and dynamic length of response, but sometimes not. In this case within one thing (status report) we see the two different approaches. Of course I can see the logic behind them, GRBL has very limited amount of memory, and extra keys would make it worse, but let's be honest: use integeres for the keys (instead of 2 chars key) and there you go. You can easily identify all the data with an exact key, and eats less memory.

_Idea_: <key_integer:single_value | >, for eg: <0:2|1:1,2,3|2:35| ... > Strict and consistent format, less memory consumption, interface writers can use enums for the keys for more readable codes. Yes, not human friendly...

2. Settings
_Request-Response_: One stream command => multiple lines response with 'ok' (worst case scenario)
_Detection_: Easy for one line, very hard and risky for the full setting list.
_Parsing_: The same as detection, easy for one line, but hard if you want the whole picture.
_Concerns_: 
- Here we have a very consistent key-value pair list, with integer keys (as I advised for the status report above), but we have a new separator: '='. That's the only case when the key-value separator is '='. Yeah, it's not a big deal, like this whole thread, but still, worth to mention. These are just my small concerns. It's just extra complexity without any benefit.
- This is my biggest issue: The whole one line request, multiple lines response stuff is killing me. Yes, we have an 'ok' at the end of the list, just like we have one when GRBL accepts the $$ request,  but it means, you cannot have something like a generic ResponseProcessor<T> which accepts a response and handle it. In this very case the read and write parts are tightly coupled, a CQRS solution is could be pretty tricky. It looks like, I have two option at this point: ignore the OK message at the end of the list and go with the easily identifiable lines which start with $<number>, in which case I have no idea when all the settings are known for me, or option#2: write a mini state machine only for the setting printout, which knows about the starting and ending ok. That would be cool, if it would be useful anywhere elsewhere, but it's not. It's just the big extra complexity for one time. Also there is the possibility that something terrible happens meanwhile I'm listing the settings, for eg a limit switch triggered, which will send an immediate push message in the middle of my state machine.

_Idea_:  
- First and foremost: get rid of the multi line solution. There should be only one line response for each request. Use the standard ':' key-value separator and the pipe between them. Yes, human readability again, but I'm not sure how much should it matter when it's about interfacing, and since line endings play a big role in our communication, it should be used very carefully, not like this. $0:1|1:123.456|2:3 ... Looks ugly? Yes, just like the status report, but still, UI writers can display it whatever fancy format they wish to. Or make a configuration in config.h for this format if readability is such a concern.

But it getting worse:

3. GCode Parameters:
_Request-Response_: One stream command => multiple lines response with 'ok' (worst case scenario)
_Detection_: Nightmare. There's no easy way to identify a parameter response only if you exactly know what you expect (again: read and write tightly coupled, or the responses are hard coded)
_Parsing_: Inconsistent. The key-value separator is ':' but there's exactly one exception without any good reason (PRB has two values, with the very same separator)
_Concerns_: 
- The one request => multi line response is the worse here since you can't even identify a single line easily. The first character is commonly used elsewhere (all the feedback messages start with '['). The only solution is a hardcoded list, which contains all the optional keys (G54, G28 G92, TLO, PRB, ...). That is the only case, when you cannot identify a line at a glance. No special starter character, no static key. Nothing.  If we would have a special character to identify a line as parameter response it would be at least the same as the Settings. But no. It's a 3rd case, without a single good reason.
- The PRB parameter makes it even worse, because we have 2 values for one key but with the very same separator. 

_Idea_:  Anything else. That's just stupid. All keys should have one and only one value. All the lines must be easily identifiable as a parameter response. And the multi line situation makes it even worse. Like always, the solution is the very same as always (exactly that's the point of the consistency):  One request => one line response, with key-value pairs (where the keys are integers). ':' as key-value separator, and pipe as pair separator. 

4. GCode Parser State:
_Request-Response_: One stream command => one line response with multiple data.
_Detection_: Could be much better, since the first char is not dominant here, you need to read the start of the line to identify the line as parser state. It's just impossible to use something like this:  https://i.imgur.com/WmcjIRR.png You have to write sub-processors without any reason for feedbackMessages.
_Parsing_: Not fun, but not bad. I like the way it works tho. The T/S/F parameters are exceptions, but I have no better idea for it. It makes sense, that T/S/F is part of the parser state and they are numbers, so yeah. I can live with it. A separate parser state response only for these 3 parameter would be too much I guess?
_Concerns_: 
- First char is not dominant (feedback message, but it's a special kind of feedback message). Why do we have to reuse feedback message so many times? Parser state is a very important information, and the UI use it heavily. It deserves a dedicated starter char (like all the responses). I mean, I can live without unique first chars, but it looks like we have a few of them, why don't we have for all the responses? Consistency again.
- Also the T/S/F parameters are exception, but I have no better idea, so let's skip this one.

_Idea_:  Replace [GC: to a unique char and I'm a happy man (who cares, I know)


I have many other concerns/ideas like these, but I it's already too long. I'd be happy to have a discussion about these.

And yes, my english is awful, and I probably made hundreds of errors. I'm working on it, please excuse me on this one.

title: Startup message sends no "ok"

title: Possible hard limits issue
body:
In the LIMIT_INT_vect function you call mc_reset() and then set EXEC_ALARM_HARD_LIMIT - which gets picked up by a protocol loop that looks to want to wait for the user to do something - but it doesn't wait because of the flag set in mc_reset (sys_rt_exec_state = EXEC_RESET).

protocol_exec_rt_system runs the loop once and sees it's time to leave because of the reset flag.

Perhaps saving and restoring sys_rt_exec_state around the call to mc_reset() in the hard limits interrupt would be better?

title: CoreXY homing issue
body:
Hello, I built a CoreXY machine with Arduino Mega and RAMPS 1.4. I am using grbl-Mega fork v1.1f but since I think the Mega fork has only minor changes, this issue could be answered there too.

Basically I have a problem with homing - only one motor moves at a time. That would be fine with Cartesian machine, but it is a problem with CoreXY one. One thing to mention - jogging works fine, moving in either X or Y moves both motors at a time, so the motion is in the direction I want. But that is not the case with homing.

I altered these lines in config.h:
- uncommented #define COREXY
- added #define INVERT_MIN_LIMIT_PIN_MASK ((1<<X_AXIS) | (1<<Y_AXIS)) - limit switches now work properly
- uncommented #define HOMING_CYCLE_0 (1<<X_AXIS) and #define HOMING_CYCLE_1 (1<<Y_AXIS)
- uncommented #define HOMING_FORCE_SET_ORIGIN - I am used to 3D printers so for starters I would like to use "positive workspace"

I changed these eeprom constants via commands:
- $0 = 3
- $1 = 100

Any ideas how to make homing work properly?

title: Understanding control state logic
body:
Hello, I'm running GRBL 1.1f. I have only one "control" wired up and that is `CONTROL_SAFETY_DOOR_BIT`. The switch is Normally Closed so I also
`#define INVERT_CONTROL_PIN_MASK ((1<<CONTROL_SAFETY_DOOR_BIT))`

Looking at the code [here](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/blob/master/grbl/system.c#L47), we enter the block if at least one pin is raised. Then we ask a number of `bit_isfalse` questions. This seems odd to me. If something is `true` we enter the block and try to find something that is `false`. If my door is ajar, the result of `bit_isfalse(pin,(1<<CONTROL_SAFETY_DOOR_BIT))` is `true`. I'm not sure it matters that I've got just the one control, but when the `CONTROL_SAFETY_DOOR_BIT` is not set, the test on `pin` is also false and it never enters the block.

I have to comment out the block `if (pin) {` in order to get my door switch working.

Have I done something odd? Unexpected? How does this work for anybody at all? I expect `CONTROL_SAFETY_DOOR_BIT` to be `true` when there is a problem, so the `if (pin) {` seems proper, but then I would expect a test on `bit_istrue` on the `CONTROL_SAFETY_DOOR_BIT`.

Am I making any sense?

Thanks.

/Daryl

title: Incorrect sanity check of spindle configuration values in grbl.h
body:
In grbl.h there are sanity checks for the #define configuration.
In row 71 is a error check for the spindle configuration: `#if defined(USE_SPINDLE_DIR_AS_ENABLE_PIN) && !defined(VARIABLE_SPINDLE)` and config.h contains a corresponding comment `// NOTE: This configure option only works with VARIABLE_SPINDLE enabled and a 328p processor (Uno).`

This check is in my opinion neither correct nor usefull.

The usecase which this collides with, is an simple "on/off" spindle without direction or PWM.
When configuring this usecase my assumption would be to #define `USE_SPINDLE_DIR_AS_ENABLE_PIN` (with both outputs configured to be on the same port/pin) in order to disable the output of an direction signal, and remove `#define VARIABLE_SPINDLE` to disable PWM.

In my opinion there is no code in spindle_control.c that would break by this configuration.

In summary i would consider this check unnecessary/incorrect and would suggest to revisit it's substantiation with the target of to removing it.

title: Update Woodpecker CNC GRBL 0.9 to 1.1f
body:
Hello, I just recently decided to update my Chinese “Woodpecker CNC Board” to the most up-to-date grbl Version 1.1f. 

I found [Mariano Gaston’s YouTube video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kJRy3_heliQ) that promises the feasibility of this procedure and shows the necessary connections.  I also read the issue about connecting limit switches to this board (https://github.com/gnea/grbl/issues/123)  and as mentioned there I re-checked all pins from the header regarding there mapping to the 328P. For some reason I can’t get a direct connection between the pin associated with MISO and its counterpart on the chip itself. The connection seems to be bridged by something – maybe a diode? Nevertheless, I tried to connect my programmer (usbasp-clone and ArduinoISP). - Long story short, after several ours of fiddling around I finally managed to brick my controller board.

I know this is most probably not an issue with GRBL itself and thus should not be posted as an issue for that, but I have no idea where to look for support regarding this specific problem. So sorry for that, but any help is highly appreciated!

Following first what I’ve done to kill the board and then what I’ve tried to get it back up.

As described above I am using an [usbasp-clone](https://de.aliexpress.com/item/USBasp-USB-ISP-3-3V-5V-AVR-Programmer-USB-ATMEGA8-ATMEGA128-New-10PIN-Wire-Support-Win7/32536193605.html) and an [Arduino Nano as ArduinoISP](http://www.martyncurrey.com/arduino-nano-as-an-isp-programmer/). From the begin on I had problems connecting the Woodpecker using the usbasp-clone, so I mostly tried to update with the avrisp. With all connection in place and the external power supply connected I got something like this from avrdude:

`$ avrdude -c avrisp -p m328p -P com6 -b 19200 -B 100

avrdude.exe: AVR device initialized and ready to accept instructions

Reading | ################################################## | 100% 0.02s

avrdude.exe: Device signature = 0x0fca07
avrdude.exe: Expected signature for ATmega328P is 1E 95 0F
             Double check chip, or use -F to override this check.

avrdude.exe done.  Thank you.`

After several hours I thought it would be a great idea to just modify Arduino’s avrdude configuration to expect this device signature. I clicked the “Burn bootloader” entry, it did something and then crashed. I’ve got no log from that procedure but now, the board is not serial-printing its version number on startup anymore.

Since then I’ve tried many different configurations, with and without external power supply using windows and linux hosts, testing my programmers with other 328p chips, etc. 
My current test is just an avrdude invocation to query the device signature. Both programmers are working, I verified that with the other chip. For that reason, I assume the programmer-side wiring is correct as well. I checked the wiring to the Woodpecker board multiple times and for the MISO pin that is connected via an unknown component I also tried to bypass it by connecting the wire directly to the atmega pin.
Using the usbasp-clone I always get an ‘initialization failed’ (windows and linux host). With the ArduinoISP I get two different responses depending on the attachment of the programmers VCC line - despite the external supply – It’s either `0x0fca07` (with connected VCC) or `0x1f9f0f` (with disconnected VCC) but never 0x1e950f what it should be. I tried different values for the -B parameter without any success.

So, any suggestions?

title: bCNC  "ALARM:3" status makes me crazy.
body:
Hi everyone,

Beginning 2017 I have built my own CNC.

At the beginning, everything was running fine without limit switches.
After installing limit switches, I became almost by every run an alarm, this problem was clear and fixed after installing opto couplers between the switches and the Arduino.

Now, we are several months further and time to time the CNC stops without a visible reason.
In bCNC, the “ALARM: 3” status shows up.

Not good… the manual says "Reset while in motion". 
-	Grbl cannot guarantee position. 
-	Lost steps are likely. 
-	Re-homing is highly recommended.

I cannot find the reason why this behavior occurs, and where it comes from.
I hope that someone here can give me a tip where I can start searching to fix this problem for good.

In the meantime, at the end of the motor cables (as close as possible to the Arduino), like also on the power cable of the Dewalt 611 router, I installed ferrite suppression filters, unfortunately without any result, the machine goes occasionally into alarm phase 3.
 
1.	Where can I start to search what is happening here?
2.	I cannot find log files of GRBL or bCNC, where are they stored??

Any help is welcome and much appreciated !

Best regards,
Benny

title: Step generation accuracy - worst case scenarios?
body:
Hi,

I've been doing a bit of research into the accuracy of step profiles generated by stepper motor controllers like grbl.  I found a few cases where the width of steps is +-1/3rd of the ideal step, see here for details:

https://xenovacivus.github.io/jekyll/2017/12/23/stepper-motor-driver-accuracy.html

The short/long steps clearly aren't an issue, otherwise there would be some complaints.  They average out pretty quickly - especially with microstepping.  Has anyone else done testing to see what the absolute worst case is though?  And is the state-of-the-art approach for testing step profiles still "Run some GCode and see how the machine performs."?

title: Status report request (?) sends 'ok' as respond
body:
Based on the latest documentation [here ](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/wiki/Grbl-v1.1-Interface): 

> Push messages are easily identified because they **don't start with an ok or error** like response messages do. They are typically placed in [] brackets, <> chevrons, start with a $, or a specific string of text.

When: I send a `?` command (real-time status report request) to the GRBL

**Expected**
Then: Grbl should response with the status report (between chevrons) - as the the documentation states

**Actual**
Then: Grbl response with the status report AND send back an `ok` message as well as two separated line.

Let's say I'm implementing basic streaming protocol for GRBL, which waits for `ok` response before a new command will be sent. Theoretically the `?` request is a big exception since I can send it with 200 ms delays over and over again, regardless of other commands, or at least that's what the documentation says under the 'Status Reporting' section:

>The ? is always picked-off and removed from the serial receive buffer whenever Grbl detects one. So, these can be sent at any time. Also, to make it a little easier for GUIs to pick up on status reports, they are always encased by <> chevrons.

If I send a command to GRBL (for eg.: I'm streaming a *.nc file line-by-line) I'll have to wait for an `ok` response between every lines, but a polling solution is also running in the background and sending `?` requests to GRBL on another thread with low frequency. I can't really match the request-response pairs, because the very same response will be sent to me via GRBL. The next `ok` may be the matching pair for my status report request or for the last line from the *.nc file.

It looks like I should suspend the polling everytime when I'm waiting for an `ok` response, but the documentation is not very clear in this topic, also makes false statements.

title: CNC no Homing
body:
First attempt to resolve issue with Mfr:
I wiped GRBL1.1 and reloaded to Arduino Uno.  Then after trying to reinvent the wheel, discovered the table of default values for GRBL settings in the Assembly instructions.  I thought that would fix everything, but alas, no.  Homing will not work.  First, the z-axis motor moves down, instead of up.  (Yes, $23=3), but then it immediately stops with an Alarm 8 code.  Help!  There are other issues with jogging just freezing after a few jogs, but I think it may be related to the fact that I cannot home the machine & it thinks that I am exceeding soft limits.  Maybe/maybe not, but I think/hope that solving the homing issue will resolve all other issues.  Any advice?  Need info?
Response:
Please see the troubleshooting guide for reversing the direction of the stepper motor. https://www.bobscnc.com/products/e3-cnc-engraving-kit.  Z should move in the up direction when homed.
Me:
Ok, I have reviewed the document.  Still won't home correctly.  The stepper motors run in the correct direction when I jog the machine.  The spindle moves down, incorrectly, ONLY while homing.  Per your instructions, I set $23=3 to reverse X & Y for homing (limit switches are negative direction), but leave Z the same (limit switch is up/positive direction).  But when homing, the spindle immediately starts down. After brief movement, I get the error message, "An error was detected while sending '$H': (ALARM:8) Homing fail. Pull off travel failed to clear limit switch. Try increasing pull-off setting or check wiring.  Streaming has been paused."  This followed immediately by a second error message, "Error while processing response: An unexpected command was completed by the controller."  The wiring is fine.  I even replaced the X home switch that was showing a higher resistance (bad solder joint).  I have tried so many different settings that I am now completely confused and frustrated.  When I put my E3 together the first time, it worked perfectly.  Now it is a desk sculpture.  I even reloaded Netbeans-UGS and tried 3 different versions:  ugsplatform (most recent nightly rebuild), UniversalGcodeSender-v1.0.6, and UniversalGcodeSender-v1.0.9.  None look like my original and I can no longer find that file on the website.  The ugsplatform is most similar, but it does not have the x, y, z check boxes in the Controller State window as described in your recommended help document.

I think this detail may be important:  When I jog X+, the gantry moves to the right (away from home switch) and the Controller State windows shows the X position getting bigger.  Good!  BUT.  It is a negative number rising toward zero.  When it reaches zero, the gantry stops and I get an error message, "An error was detected while sending '$J=G21G91X1F500': (error:15) Jog target exceeds machine travel.  Jog command has been ignored. Streaming has been paused."  That is, the system is working in negative space!

I understand if you plead to being a mechanical guy, rather than a software guy.  But I need help!  Any & all advice welcome, even referral to a GRBL help site for old guys who long for the TurboBasic days.  Christmas IS coming and I have gifts to make!

Ok, folks, the above is not meant to disparage Bob's CNC.  I works great and I have been happy.  But I need help to get my Christmas "shop-ping" done!  This feels like I am overlooking something simple, but I can't figure it out.  Anyone?  Buehler?  Buehler?

title: What are hard and soft requirements for the pinout?
body:
I'm building a hybrid CNC/3D Printer using the Arduino Nano with grbl and Teacup as respective firmwares. These have different pinouts, so I'm looking into the possibilities of landing on a common pinout compatible with both firmwares.

grbl has a few requirements defined in cpu_map.h, most notably a few comments such as  

`// NOTE: All direction pins must be on the same port.`

These seem like clear invariants, but there's also a few such as 

`// // NOTE: All limit bit pins must be on the same port, but not on a port with other input pins (CONTROL).`

These are less clear. Does this mean that while the limit switches *must* be on the same port, there's no such requirement across limit and control switches, or does this mean that limits and control *must not* be on the same port?

The arduino supports using the analog ports as digital; what flexibility exists in e.g. moving the limit switches to the analog PORTB in order to free up the digital pins for an extra stepper?

title: UGS is showing this [Detallado]<Idle|MPos:0.000,0.000,0.000|FS:0,0> all the time.
body:
Hi all!

I found this amazing firmware while looking for an affordable CNC controller and GCode interpreter. Thank you very much to the authors and contributor for bringing this marvelous piece of code available for all!

I used Galil, Fagor and Siemens in other applications but I was interested in a really affordable option intended for a more wide public.
I was very exited by the reading and went to shopping next day to buy an Arduino UNO board to start playing with it.

All the start up is very straight forward so no comments on it. Case is that I had just the tiny Arduino board on the desk connected to a PC by a EMI protected USB cable and the UGS running and started to "move" the axis and sending some commands. All worked fine, but I discovered an unchecked box that will let me jog the axis with the keypad, so I enabled the option and started to push the keys to see what happen... and all went great until I kept the Y+ key pressed for a while. Suddenly the Alarm changed to red and the TX and RX LEDs on the board start to blinking and the verbose shows a MPos at 0,0,0 in a continue scroll. I was not able to stop this anymore. I killed the Allarm... nothing happened. I reloaded the firmware.. no way. I erase the GRBL folder, created a new one, downloaded all the software again, installed them, added the GRBL library in the Arduino IDE and downloaded the GRBL Firmware to the board using XLoader... Nothing changed. Every time I connect the Arduino to the USB I have those LEDs blinking and the massage with the zero position scrolling in the monitor.
Lastly and as an ultimate option, I bought a brand new ATmega 328P-PU, put it on the board, burned the bootloader, and started as a new one and... do you know what? Yes! those LEDs are still blinking and the verbose output scrolling!!
I was not able to find any variable that might retain a value to keep this situation on. I even loaded an EEPROM eraser to clean the processor memory but no luck with this neither. So, if the event is not saved in the ATmega328, nor in the PC disk (I deleted all the GRBL related directories twice) where has been this alarm event stored. What I should make to restore the board (or entire system Ardino + GRBL) to its initial stage and behavior?
It seems to me that it will work OK when I assemble the machine and the controller can find the limit switches and perform the homing cycle but in the meantime I am struggling with all this.

Thank you very much, in advance, for all the help and advice you can provide to me. It will be much appreciated!

I'm writing a custom serial interface and having to do some intricate work in the code to separate out the "ok"s from gcode sends and "ok"s from other realtime commands (e.g. status). Ed

title: Homing in three cycles
body:
By now I used our GRBL controlled Stepcraft router without homing. So if something went wrong I completeley lost the workpiece position. Last week I decided to change that. ;-)

Unfortuneately the Stepcraft fires no specific signals, if the reference switches are hit. That means GRBL just gets the same signal for switch Z, X and Y. No problem so far. Instead of a two cycle homing (first Z, then X and Y as default) I have to change it to a three cycle homing (each axis separetely).

Default settings in config.h:
(see also https://github.com/gnea/grbl/blob/master/grbl/config.h#L105)
```#define HOMING_CYCLE_0 (1<<Z_AXIS)
#define HOMING_CYCLE_1 ((1<<X_AXIS)|(1<<Y_AXIS))
// #define HOMING_CYCLE_2
```

I changed these lines to:
```
#define HOMING_CYCLE_0 (1<<Z_AXIS)
#define HOMING_CYCLE_1 (1<<X_AXIS)
#define HOMING_CYCLE_2 (1<<Y_AXIS)
```

That was easy! But nothing changed! The router keeps homing in two cycles. :(

What I tried so far:
- deleted all the precompiled files unter "C:\compiled\libraries\grbl" (working on W10)...
- deleted all the GRBL files and started from scratch...

For me it looks like my bloody computer uploads the unaltered code. How can I verify wether that's a fact or not?

title: Porting to ATmega2561 Intrrupts
body:
Has anyone ported GRBL on to an ATmega2561?

As far as I can see the ATmega2561 has only 1 port which handles pin change interrupts (PCINT) Unlike the ATmega2560 and the ATmega328.  GRBL needs two ports one to handle the hard limits and one to handle the control pins. 

The Atmega2561 does have other interrupts (INT). From what I understand these interrupts only triger when they are pulled low. whilst the pin change interrupts trigger if the pin changes from low to high or it changes fom high to low.

Can I use these INT instead of the PCINT ? if so how would you impliment this?

title: Recover from last command guidelines (UI development)
body: Hi all. I am trying to develop a function to help the user to recover an interrupted job (hang, reset, disconnection) continuing from the very last command "fully executed" from Grbl when streaming a G-Code file. The info I know are the last command that receive a "OK/ERROR" response and the last command I have send through the COM. The operation I use to do for resume are: - ask the user from where to restart (position) suggesting some significant options - analyze the file until this position and compute last speed, power, and state of laser as well G90/G91 absolute and relative coordinates - analyze the file and compute the correct final coordinates of the previous command Then I: - send a $H homing to fix uncertain position (optional) - send a fast move to that coordinate - reapply speed, power, state and G90/91 - enqueue the file starting from that position [](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UwJAFp1pS-I) This work quite well, but I see that the "OK" response does not arrive when the command is "fully executed" but only when it is transferred to the planned buffer (i think). So the job doesn't start exatly from where left, but some step onward/next. I can obviously get back arbitrarily from some commands: the risk to double overwrite some parts is less annoying than left some missing part. However i ask: Is there a simple way to guess what is the very last "completely executed command"?

title: Buffer size is 128 or 127?
body:
[Somewere](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/wiki/Grbl-v1.1-Interface#streaming-protocol-simple-send-response-recommended) I can read that buffer size is 127

> Grbl essentially has two buffers between the execution of steps and the host PC interface. One of them is the serial receive buffer. This briefly stores up to 127 characters

[In the same document](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/wiki/Grbl-v1.1-Interface#streaming-protocol-character-counting-recommended-with-reservation) I can read that buffer size is 128

> We know Grbl has a 128 character serial receive buffer, and the host PC can send up to 128 characters without overflowing the buffer

With $10=2 I can activate the report of Buffer State, and it show a value of 128

> Buffer State:
Bf:15,128. The first value is the number of available blocks in the planner buffer and the second is number of available bytes in the serial RX buffer.

What is definitely the buffer size?
It was changed from v0.9 and v1.1?

Thank you :-)

title: Hi All... I think the most updated version of Lasergrbl is 1.1 but I  saw a version n2.8 on SOFTPEDIA.com? Can anyone confirm what this might be?
Slow start / spindle ramp-up
body:
Hi,
every time I enable my spindle with max rpm, my psu voltage drops drastically, because the spindle initially draws a huge current. This causes problems and sometimes the controller resets.
Also, the high inrush current is bad for the connectors and motor brushes.
It would be a nice feature, if grbl supported a ramp-up setting where the spindle would actually be slowly ramped up/down to the speed set via S command.
Guess this would be helpful for lots of cheap boards with simple mosfet spindle controller without extra inrush current protection. What do you think?

title: What is the expected behavior of spindle enable in Laser Mode?
body: With Laser Mode enabled and USE_SPINDLE_DIR_AS_ENABLE_PIN set, is the spindle enable pin supposed to toggle when switching between G0/G1 movement modes, or will it only turn off when the Laser is disabled completely with an M5? Our Laser needs to be run with a constant PWM and turned on and off using the enable pin in order to respond quickly enough at engraving speeds.

title: CH340 and speed setting
body:
Hi all

This is not an issue, just an idea and a data point.

Serial speeds are not exact multiples of the Arduino clock and I had this idea that maybe by selecting an exact multiple we can reduce or remove the problems with CH340 USB chips.

To this end I looked up the speeds available for the CH340.
I set mine to 128000 on config.h , flashed GRBL 1.1 and then ran a couple of big files through it.  First one was about 40 minutes of cut time, second was 1H33.    GUI was Candle.  USB cable is a decent one with ferrite filters.

128000 is exactly 1/125 of the 16mhz clock, whereas for all the common serial speeds there is some clock error.

Result?  no errors in comms so far.   I will continue to throw Gcode at this testbed (just a clone UNO lying on my desk) and see what happens.

title: XY (non-Z) homing without a recompile
body:
Hi,

Apologies if this has already been covered, but I haven't managed to find anything on it.

There's a great howto on setting up homing here: https://github.com/gnea/grbl/wiki/Set-up-the-Homing-Cycle

However I have a laser engraver with no Z axis, and homing with `$H` searches on Z first. It looks like I can simply rebuild with a tweaked `config.h`, which is awesome and which I will do.

... However, would it be possible to maybe make `limits_go_home` check the steps/mm or max speed setting for the axis it is checking? That way, anyone without a Z axis (or without Z homing) could take a totally standard binary, set `$102=0`, and have it work perfectly with limit switches without a rebuild?

Either that or the $22 homing cycle could take a numeric value, where there were different options for homing style.

Anyway, just an idea for an enhancement - it'll work great as-is with a rebuild.

title: Gcode G81 works great with grbl/bCNC
body:
Hi all,
one month ago I was very surprise to see that grbl1.1/bCNC0.9/arduino Uno+cnc shield v.3  did a very nice holes and work with Gcode using G81...?..!
This Gcode was generated by Freecad 0.17 set with Linuxcnc as post processor
tool : driller 5mm for hole 5mm 
....
....
G0 F50.000000 Z6.000000
G0 F150.000000 X11.430000 Y-8.630000
G0 F50.000000 Z6.000000
G81 F25.000000 R1.000000 X11.430000 Y-8.630000 Z-8.000000
G81 F25.000000 R1.000000 X58.570000 Y-8.630000 Z-8.000000
....
for a total of 15 holes  on this work.
Before this test to drill  holes I transformed the G81 like this:
G0Z10
G0 X112.5 Y-15.0
G0Z0.5
G1 Z-7 F25
G0 Z12

in fact with G81 grbl/bcnc it does exactly the same thing (speed for G0 and G1...).
I tested the same thing with a lot of software (like grblpanel, candle panel, universal Gcode it 's not work

since I did near 500 holes  on aluminium (from 2mm to 15mm depth) with not any problems

Does someone have an idea about that ?
I can tell you that for me it's fantastic I save a lot of time

Best

title: Modal group violation when using M7 and M8 on the same line
body:
Using M7 (Mist coolant) and M8 (Flood coolant) on the same line will report a modal group violation error. I used to workaround this issue with separate lines, but I think Grbl should allow M7 and M8 on the same line.

```
M7
ok
M8
ok
M7 M8
error:21 (Modal group violation)
```

title: Why did you close an issue before I've finished.
body:
I'm trying to get the $SLP command to work and asked for help, half way through the issue was closed.
That's not really very helpful. 
I started with this:

> I use LaserGRBL with a genuine Arduino UNO with GRBL 1.1 installed and have Easydrivers to drive my motors.
> There is a sleep connection on the Easydrivers which is set to normally high.
> At the minute I don't have anything connected to it.
> This is from Easydrivers website:
> "SLP (sleep) : This normally high input signal will minimize power consumption by disabling internal circuitry and the output drivers when pulled low."
> What I'd like to know is do I need to link a wire from one the Arduino pins to the SLP connector to enable $SLP to work.
> At the minute when I type the command in LaserGRBL it responds with:
> [MSG:Sleeping] but does not actually do anything, everything is still powered including the motors.

chamnit replied and said:

> Grbl's sleep command just disables the stepper enable pin, based on your $4 step enable invert setting. It's not tied to your stepper driver sleep pin.

and then he closed the issue.

What I was going to ask next was:

> So do I need to connect the Enable pin on the Easydriver to the Arduino.
> Because I've just made $4=1 and it still does'nt work.

> On the Easydriver the Enable pin is this:
> "ENABLE : This normally low input signal will disable all outputs when pulled high."

Any chance someone might now the answer.

title: gcode optimization rules for grbl

My questions are:

title: PWM min/max seems to have no effect
body:
Well, I'm sure it's my fault! But I can't understand my mistake. I'm trying gtbl 1.1f in laser mode, constant power (M3). The first thing is to calibrate min and max PWM to get nice shades of gray. I did the following:

1. very simple gcode test:
`G90
F4000
G0 X0 Y0
M3 S0 M8
G4 P2

G91
G1 F2000 X10 S255
X10 S200
X10 S150
X10 S100
X10 S50
X10 S1
G0 X0 Y0.2
G1 X-10 S1
X-10 S50
X-10 S100
X-10 S150
X-10 S200
X-10 S255
G0 X0 Y0.2
....
`

2. set $31=0 $30=255 and give it a try. As expected the lighter shades are not engraved - OK

3. to feel the opposite limits I set $31=200 and $30=255.... the behavior is VERY similar!

The docs says:
`
By default, Grbl linearly relates the max-min RPMs to 5V-0.02V PWM pin output in 255 equally spaced increments. 
`

As far I as understand it should take my input values (0-255, very handy for 8-bit grayscale images by the way) and map them between 200 and 255 in equally spaced increments. It doesn't happen - I still get VERY low power on most shades but the darkest one (that is likely 100%).

How should I calibrate those values for nice shades?

title: CNC Shield GRBL Limit Switch not Working
body:
I'm using the ubiquitous "CNC shield" with GRBL 1.1 and an Arduino UNO clone. The shield has a section called "END STOPS" with 6 pairs of pins X+, X-, Y+,Y-,Z+,Z-.

My assumption was when (assuming $21=1) I short or unshort X+ the machine will stop moving in the positive X direction. That's not the case. It occasionally works but in general $21 makes grbl unresponsive. I've checked the pins of the switch - they are ground and high (5v) so I assume a pullup is provided.

What's the correct way to wire the limit/stop switches to a *CNC shield*?:
* Normal open/normal closed?
* Capacitors
* Pull up resistors?
