title: Pins options + Spindle Wiring
body:
In a week, I'll be making my electronics box and setting up the new machine!
1)Does anyone know where to wire the PWM and Spin Ena pins on a HuanYang VFD? 

2) Can I have a relay control the stepper motors PSU? It'd be cool to have the whole box basically shut itself off via the arduino. Any pin option for that? If not, I'll just use an on/off toggle.

3)How does the feed hold pin work? I'd like to add my E-stop button, but without just losing power to the drives and my work position. The switch has one NO and one NC circuit, so if there was some way I can have it Feed hold when I engage the switch, then reset when I pop the switch out? Is that possible or will it just constantly reset itself as long as the circuit is complete. 

Thanks!

Here is my current wiring set up: http://imgur.com/gaNQ0eL

(I'll also be posting this elsewhere but ask that they respond here)

title: Semi-Random Z-Axis Pulses
body:
Hello,

I've run into an issue with a machine I'm using, where the z-axis stepper driver is receiving pulses and moving when it shouldn't be. I've only seen this happen when the x-axis is moving in the negative direction and the y-axis is moving in the positive direction simultaneously. During this kind of move, the z-axis stepper driver will sometimes pick up 1-3 pulses at once, gradually bringing it out of position over the course of a long run.

I've been able to work around this for my purposes, but any ideas as to what might be causing it?

Thanks!

This gcode snippet is enough to observe the issue:
```
G0 G54 G17 G21 G90 G94 T0 F0.0 S0
G10 P0 L20 X0 Y0 Z0
G1 F800
G0 X100 Y0
G1 X0 Y150
```

My $$:
```
$0 = 10    (Step pulse time, microseconds)
$1 = 25    (Step idle delay, milliseconds)
$2 = 0    (Step pulse invert, mask)
$3 = 6    (Step direction invert, mask)
$4 = 0    (Invert step enable pin, boolean)
$5 = 0    (Invert limit pins, boolean)
$6 = 0    (Invert probe pin, boolean)
$10 = 1    (Status report options, mask)
$11 = 0.010    (Junction deviation, millimeters)
$12 = 0.002    (Arc tolerance, millimeters)
$13 = 0    (Report in inches, boolean)
$20 = 0    (Soft limits enable, boolean)
$21 = 1    (Hard limits enable, boolean)
$22 = 1    (Homing cycle enable, boolean)
$23 = 1    (Homing direction invert, mask)
$24 = 25.000    (Homing locate feed rate, mm/min)
$25 = 500.000    (Homing search seek rate, mm/min)
$26 = 250    (Homing switch debounce delay, milliseconds)
$27 = 3.000    (Homing switch pull-off distance, millimeters)
$30 = 1000    (Maximum spindle speed, RPM)
$31 = 0    (Minimum spindle speed, RPM)
$32 = 0    (Laser-mode enable, boolean)
$100 = 40.000    (X-axis travel resolution, step/mm)
$101 = 55.385    (Y-axis travel resolution, step/mm)
$102 = 25.000    (Z-axis travel resolution, step/mm)
$110 = 1400.000    (X-axis maximum rate, mm/min)
$111 = 1060.000    (Y-axis maximum rate, mm/min)
$112 = 1000.000    (Z-axis maximum rate, mm/min)
$120 = 10.000    (X-axis acceleration, mm/sec^2)
$121 = 10.000    (Y-axis acceleration, mm/sec^2)
$122 = 10.000    (Z-axis acceleration, mm/sec^2)
$130 = 200.000    (X-axis maximum travel, millimeters)
$131 = 2000.000    (Y-axis maximum travel, millimeters)
$132 = 200.000    (Z-axis maximum travel, millimeters)
```

My $I:
```
[echo: $I]
[VER:1.1f.20170131:]
[OPT:,15,128]
```

body:
I think I'm missing something somewhere.  I have an old serial machine that I have converted to use grbl.  It has a safety door that I'd love to use with my current setup.  Right now just testing on an Arduino Uno, using the latest release, I modified config.h to ENABLE_SAFETY_DOOR_INPUT_PIN and PARKING_ENABLE, but I am not seeing what I expected.  The feed hold pin on the Uno works as it did before.  When I ground it, I enter a HOLD : 0 state and I have to cycle start to resume. Thanks

title: G28 Homing only Z
body: On my CNC, I have a tool that impacts the work surface instead of drilling into it. As a result, my Z axis occasionally becomes uncalibrated. I could home after every impact, but it would increase the time significantly. I did some research, and I believe the G28 command is typically used for homing only the Z axis. This would significantly reduce time.

title: CAMWorks GRBL postprocessor
body:
Just in case someone will use GRBL with CAM module for SolidWorks that will become official SolidWorks' CAM module next year (http://blogs.solidworks.com/solidworksblog/2017/02/introducing-solidworks-cam-smart-manufacturing-ecosystem.html). And the best CAM embedded in SolidWorks tested so far. Here is the simplest possible postprocessor for our controller. 

It supports linear and arc moves, variable spindle speed and no tool length compensation. 
Just unzip it somewhere on hard drive and point CamWorks to it
 Machine->Edit definition->Post processor tab->Browse->Select
Make sure you've selected it right:
![29-07-2017 17-09-13](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3776738/28743966-d1418c82-7480-11e7-9481-821028cc14a7.jpg)

[grbl_post.zip](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/files/1184860/grbl_post.zip)

Disclaimer: I'm really a newbie at G-code and/or CamWorks, so THE FILE IS PROVIDED AS_IS with no warranties. Try it first in the air before you crash your machine.

title: laser engraving: M4 vs M3
body:
Hello, I'm playing with laser engraving. I'm using inkscape/bCNC/grbl1.1 to control the process and the hardware.
I'm experimenting with engraving text, so in inkscape I defined 3 textlines with different sizes.
What I observe is that with the M3 start codes everything is done but heavily. With the M4 start code
the engraving is _much_ nicer but some start moments are missed in the result.
Is there anything that I can test further why this happens?  Attached is a jpeg where the differences are marked, it is the smallest line from the three, the height of the 'D' is about 8 mm. With the M4 code it appears very nice but the laser is switched on too late at some points.
The g-code file is about 250kB and it is identical for both tests except the M3/M4 start code. If someone wants it I'm happy to send it.

title: I can't move With limit switches enabled, but with disabled, there's no problem
body:
Hi,
I have  a problem. 
_I installed 6 limit switches to the ends of each axes. I had interference problems. I was told to do [this](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/wiki/Wiring-Limit-Switches). With improved noise filtering, so with the resistors and capacitors. 
I did it, and the movements now were longer than a few millimeter, before it froze. 
I was told to use homing. That didn't work either. I was told, that it's because the max travel is wrong. I fixed that as well._ 

So here is the problem: 
When I enable the homing and the limit switches, set up that they are normally open, and start a homing cycle, it finishes without any problems. But after that when I move the axes, after a few movements it comes to a complete halt and tels me to soft reset. 
When no homing and no limit switches are enabled, everything works just fine. 

How can I make it work?

title: 1.1e eight short lines burning 45 degree angle problem
body:
I have a g-code file that burns 8 one inch long lines at a 45 degree angle, each one next to each other. The laser burns these lines such that they look like each 2 line set are next to each other, so it looks like there are 4 sets of two lines instead of 8 lines evenly spaced.

I'm attaching the file. This file looks OK in two different g-code simulators I have input the file into. But when actually laser burning this file onto craft plywood, the lines are not evenly spaced. Please see attachments.
Same results using Grbl 0.9i. I normally use Grbl 1.1e.

title: Homing and positive working space....again
body:
Hello there,

I am afraid I am asking the same stupid question every newbie does, but I combed different boards to find a solution, I read the FAQ and tried for three days, so please be patient with me ;)

I build my very first CNC machine, a gantry style laser engraver, modelled after an example at instructables. Astonishingly it works quite fine, the mechanics are ok, the general functions are working. I can do basic patterns and lines in manual mode (entering G-code by keyboard), the PWM for the laser works great and the first results are making me happy. The layout is according to right hand rule, so X positives moves the gantry to the right, Y should move away from me.

What is driving me crazy is the use of homing function and positive coordinates to work with LaserGRBL.
I managed to invert my homing sequence to the negative side of the working space, so homing is now bottom left of my table. The strange thing is
- the X-axis works now in positive numbers, so G90 G0 X10 moves the gantry 10mm over to the right
- the Y-axis works in negative numbers, so G90 G0 Y-10 is needed to move the laser away from me.

If I try G90 G0 Y10 the system tells me directly I am outside the soft limits and quits with an error and alarm. This makes me think I have set something set up wrong as the systems knows it must move to negative direction.
This is my settings:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12303263/27150546-f2b4140e-5147-11e7-9866-21f6d26d5aa5.png)
I uncommented HOMING_FORCE_SET_ORIGIN in config.h before compiling , as well  LIMITS_TWO_SWITCHES_ON_AXES

Sorry if anything is unclear, english is not my first language (greetings from Germany by the way).
Thank you very much for the work on this software, it is a real fun project to my son (13yo) and me to build this machine.
My background is not electrical but an engineer (processing, furnaces mostly) so I have an technical background, even though using a mill or other machines is 20 years gone. I tried relearning about coordinate systems and right hand rule.

Any help appreciated!

title: Set direction pins directly after obtaining new segment
body:
Hi,
i'm not sure if this problem will be still relevant with the new HAL, but i still want to address it.

In line 313 in stepper.c:
`// Set the direction pins a couple of nanoseconds before we step the steppers`
`DIRECTION_PORT = (DIRECTION_PORT & ~DIRECTION_MASK) | (st.dir_outbits & DIRECTION_MASK);`

The direction pins are set just a couple of ns before the steppers (with higher clock on ARMs this will be even less time), but some stepper drivers require the signals to be stable for a certain time before a step (e.g. 5us). This might cause 1 step in the wrong direction.

So it would be best to update the direction pins directly after obtaining the new segment in line 355:
`st.dir_outbits = st.exec_block->direction_bits ^ dir_port_invert_mask;`
`// Update direction...`

mfg

title: G7 Code feature for Raster image (CNC Laser)
body:
Before I came back to GRBL I use modified version of [Marlin firmware ](https://github.com/TurnkeyTyranny/buildlog-lasercutter-marlin/blob/master/Marlin/Marlin_main.cpp#L1070) combined with extension for[ inskscape](https://github.com/TurnkeyTyranny/laser-gcode-exporter-inkscape-plugin/blob/master/turnkeylaser.py#L90) to convert image to raster and feed it to my 100W CNC laser for engraving , it shows very high speed for engraving but Marlin firmware has not feature such as real time overriding code to control machine over the G-code, so I return to new GRBL release firmware with laser mode feature , but thanks to @arkypita & @svenhb ,after  couple of try with different G-code generator such as [LaserGRBL ](https://github.com/arkypita/LaserGRBL)& [GRBL-Plotter](https://github.com/svenhb/GRBL-Plotter)  and different GRBL setting I've noticed Sending a bitmap/raster image in G-Code syntax (which is designed for vector instructions) is a terrible waste of bytes due to hardware limit to current implementation on Arduino uno , it is pretty low band wide buffer for such task , according to @mayhem2408 note, "The G7 code used in the Marlin format is very effecient, but my experience with it has shown it is much more computationally intensive. The maximum feed I can get out of Marlin using G7s base64 is around F7000 before it starts to stutter, and it's not because of bandwidth. G7s base64 should be able to transfer just over 7000 pixels per second, which at 10 pixels per mm, can in theory hit a feed of over F40000. The other problem as far as GRBL is concerned, there is no room left in the Arduino Unos memory to add such a massive feature. It is something that may be added to the GRBL-Mega version as it has more room" , this is discuss page. https://github.com/arkypita/LaserGRBL/issues/38#issuecomment-302833773 
I know this wont be done on Arduino and thankfully  couple of GRBL version run on other board such STM32F103, I was wondering if official developer of this community will have plan to implement such nice feature on such STM board , thanks to [Roger Clarck, his repo ](https://github.com/rogerclarkmelbourne/Arduino_STM32)is real mature and robust and [STM32F103C8 is ](http://www.rogerclark.net/stm32f103-and-maple-maple-mini-with-arduino-1-5-x-ide/)cheap as Arduino uno with much more powerful, also couple of GRBL enthusiast such as @usbcnc @langwadt, @Meekdai, @MaxwellXyao port it to STM hardware but not officially 

![STMF103](http://www.rogerclark.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/STM32Mini.jpg)

implementation of G7 on Marlin

python function to create raster code
```python
 def generate_raster_gcode(self, curve, laserPower, altfeed=None):
...
```
code  for  G7 interpreter 
```cpp

 #ifdef LASER_RASTER
    case 7: //G7 Execute raster line
      if (code_seen('L')) laser.raster_raw_length = int(code_value());
	  if (code_seen('$')) {
		laser.raster_direction = (bool)code_value();
		destination[Y_AXIS] = current_position[Y_AXIS] + (laser.raster_mm_per_pulse * laser.raster_aspect_ratio); // increment Y axis
	  }
      if (code_seen('D')) laser.raster_num_pixels = base64_decode(laser.raster_data, &cmdbuffer[bufindr][strchr_pointer - cmdbuffer[bufindr] + 1], laser.raster_raw_length);
	  if (!laser.raster_direction) {
	    destination[X_AXIS] = current_position[X_AXIS] - (laser.raster_mm_per_pulse * laser.raster_num_pixels);
	    if (laser.diagnostics) {
          SERIAL_ECHO_START;
          SERIAL_ECHOLN("Negative Raster Line");
        }
	  } else {
	    destination[X_AXIS] = current_position[X_AXIS] + (laser.raster_mm_per_pulse * laser.raster_num_pixels);
	    if (laser.diagnostics) {
          SERIAL_ECHO_START;
          SERIAL_ECHOLN("Positive Raster Line");
        }
	  }
	  
	  laser.ppm = 1 / laser.raster_mm_per_pulse; //number of pulses per millimetre
	  laser.duration = (1000000 / ( feedrate / 60)) / laser.ppm; // (1 second in microseconds / (time to move 1mm in microseconds)) / (pulses per mm) = Duration of pulse, taking into account feedrate as speed and ppm
	  
	  laser.mode = RASTER;
	  laser.status = LASER_ON;
	  laser.fired = RASTER;
	  prepare_move();

      break;
#endif // LASER_RASTER
```

title: Microstep problems with high settings of steps/mm
body:
Hi,

I'm facing a problem that I cannot choose 1600 steps/mm for x, y and z axis. If I set them to 1600 steps/mm (even without connecting anything except the Arduino UNO), I cannot move the axes for the amount I want them to move. After one try, I have to reset GRBL.

This is the setup that does not work:
> $0 = 10    (Step pulse time, microseconds)
> $1 = 25    (Step idle delay, milliseconds)
> $2 = 0    (Step pulse invert, mask)
> $3 = 0    (Step direction invert, mask)
> $4 = 0    (Invert step enable pin, boolean)
> $5 = 0    (Invert limit pins, boolean)
> $6 = 0    (Invert probe pin, boolean)
> $10 = 1    (Status report options, mask)
> $11 = 0.010    (Junction deviation, millimeters)
> $12 = 0.002    (Arc tolerance, millimeters)
> $13 = 0    (Report in inches, boolean)
> $20 = 0    (Soft limits enable, boolean)
> $21 = 0    (Hard limits enable, boolean)
> $22 = 0    (Homing cycle enable, boolean)
> $23 = 0    (Homing direction invert, mask)
> $24 = 25.000    (Homing locate feed rate, mm/min)
> $25 = 500.000    (Homing search seek rate, mm/min)
> $26 = 250    (Homing switch debounce delay, milliseconds)
> $27 = 1.000    (Homing switch pull-off distance, millimeters)
> $30 = 1000    (Maximum spindle speed, RPM)
> $31 = 0    (Minimum spindle speed, RPM)
> $32 = 0    (Laser-mode enable, boolean)
> $100 = 1600.000    (X-axis travel resolution, step/mm)
> $101 = 1600.000    (Y-axis travel resolution, step/mm)
> $102 = 1600.000    (Z-axis travel resolution, step/mm)
> $110 = 2000.000    (X-axis maximum rate, mm/min)
> $111 = 2000.000    (Y-axis maximum rate, mm/min)
> $112 = 800.000    (Z-axis maximum rate, mm/min)
> $120 = 300.000    (X-axis acceleration, mm/sec^2)
> $121 = 200.000    (Y-axis acceleration, mm/sec^2)
> $122 = 100.000    (Z-axis acceleration, mm/sec^2)
> $130 = 200.000    (X-axis maximum travel, millimeters)
> $131 = 200.000    (Y-axis maximum travel, millimeters)
> $132 = 200.000    (Z-axis maximum travel, millimeters)

Is there any problem I do not see?

I tried:
- different g code senders
- connected and disconnected stepper drivers
- different USB cables
- two different Arduino UNOs (one original)
- GRBL 1.1f, 1.1e, 0.9j
- different configurations for steps/mm (800 works, 1000 works, 1200 works, 1400 does not work, 1600 does not work)

title: Real-time position tracking with grbl
body:
I am sorry if this is the wrong place to post this question, but I hoped someone may be able to help me add some interesting functionality to the grbl motion control, which could be applicable to multi-axis robots (but probably not CNC).
I am using the grbl-MEGA fork to control a delta robot like this: https://youtu.be/Gv5B63HeF1E
I can issue path-based motion control, but I would like to incorporate a way to follow a target position updated in real-time. The goal is to tell the robot to track an object, whose position is changing constantly. I have prototyped the robot and tracking system, using the jog commands in grbl, but I cannot get the performance I need by issuing rapid, short jog commands, as there is too much latency, and the robot follows the path in the buffer rather than taking a short-cut directly to the updated position. I have tried the jog cancel commands, but it issues a EXEC_MOTION_CANCEL, resulting in jerky motion. I think a jog_update() command, or similar that clears the planner buffer, and calls planner_recalculate() may be enough, or go one level deeper and clear the stepper segment buffer, and re-calculate within the last block, which could improve performance.
Am I going in the right direction? Does anyone have any advice for me?
Thank you so much for your help. I am very impressed with the grbl code so far!

title: Inconsistent format in csv files
body:
The format in the comma-delimited files for error codes, alarm codes, etc., have an inconsistent format.  In particular, the error code file differs from the others in that quotation marks are not used. For example, a line from the error code .csv is as follows:

1,Expected command letter,G-code words consist of a letter and a value. Letter was not found.

whereas a line from the alarm code csv is:

"1","Hard limit","Hard limit has been triggered. Machine position is likely lost due to sudden halt. Re-homing is highly recommended."

where each field is surrounded by quotes. The other csv files use this same format.

In order to make the files consistent, I would recommend that the error code csv be modified to this same format. 

Thanks,

John B

title: is there an easy way to support non-standard geometry machines?
body:
I'm looking at the maslow cnc machine ( https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1830738289/maslow-cnc-a-500-open-source-4-by-8-foot-cnc-machine ) which has a very non-standard geometry (vertical machine, motors/encoders on the top corners with the router suspended from the two motors).

The project has a very primitive g-code interpreter that it's written. I was wondering if there is an easy way to marry the kinematics code that moves the hardware that they have written with the much more mature and robust g-code handling, interpretation, and movement planning that grbl has.

due to the mechanics of the maslow, the actual motion handling is very different, so I'm hoping that there are just a few functions that would have to be overridden. the maslow is similar to a delta printer, but works by adjusting the length of the links rather than the vertical location of the ends of the links. It also uses a closed loop system instead of steppers (h-bridge to control the speed/direction of the motors and then an encoder to detect the position of the shaft)

I've done a little digging in the code and traced the command execution down through the planner, but I'm not sure what processes the results of the planning to turn it into actual machine movement. It looks like it may be in stepper.c but I'm not sure.

title: Excessive line gcode torture test
body: I have had problems lately with my grbl + arduino uno rev 3 combination lately. I had updated the grbl firmware to 1.1f and the usb interface to the latest version. I am still having trouble though. By any chance could someone test https://github.com/nathanielstenzel/bucket_mill/blob/960e67b3c1161c8d99741c011e9ab1027d35c0be/example_output/owl-trace-A3mm.gcode and see if it works for them? It has consecutive lines where the only movement was in the same direction as the last movement and it only moved 1mm.  Yes, that is far from efficient and I have that fixed in the program that I was working on that made the gcode. I wanted to bring this up though in case there is an actual problem with the position tracking in grbl. You see, while cutting away, it suddenly ends up at a deeper position than the gcode instructs it to go to. It could be that it can complete the movement on the gcode line faster than it can keep track of the position, but that is only a theory. Another theory is that the serial port buffer program from my laptop is being buggy. I hope the test material is useful.

title: M3/M4/M5 standards?
body:
I'm trying to determine the "universal" standard for these commands, in relation to both spindle and laser.

- Is `M3` always "full on" and takes no parameters?
- Is `M4 Sn` the only proper command for setting partial power?
- Does the `S` parameter take a range of 0-100 or 0-255?

Any guidance you can provide will be very helpful!

title: Inverting limit switches should not disable internal pull-up
body:
Hi,
i've understood that inverting logic of limit switches using $5=1 also leads in disabling internal pullup. I think this does not make any sense. You should physicaly read switch state same way for NC and NO switches. Only difference is that you should invert how you interpret that state in code.

I don't see how disabling internal pullup helps. Especially when most people go for NC setup because of noise, which can be partialy alleviated by using internal pullup.

**Please make inverting limit switch logic and disabling/enabling pullup a separate setting. I am sure people might want to set it independently.**


 Also there's no really need to use external resistor to prevent frying something. I don't know how this statement got into the documentation:

> NOTE: If you invert your limit pins, you will need an external pull-down resistor wired in to all of the limit pins to prevent overloading the pins with current and frying them.

it just doesn't make any sense... if connecting NC switch to arduino would fry something it would also be fried by NO switch as soon as it was triggered for the first time. I think you need to understand that there is no real electrical difference between NC and NO switches. the only difference between NC and NO is purely mechanical. they only differ in what mechanical motion makes them conduct electricity... but in the end all switches (no matter if NO or NC) are just two wires that sometimes touch and sometimes don't.

title: Homing cycle freezes
body:
I'm in the process of adding limit switches to my CNC machine. I have verified that my steppers and switches are wired correctly; as they move correctly on G0 and G1 commands, and they trigger the hard limits.

***The problem***
When I enable homing, and trigger it with `$H`, my machine just freezes. None of the axes move, the serial goes silent. The steppers are 'singing' though (not sure how to describe that), holding the axes locked. The only way out is a hard reset.

I've deduced (by way of random `write_serial`), that the first call to `st_wake_up()` never returns. The interrupt-driven operation of stepper.c is beyond my ability to debug, though.

***My setup***
I'm using grbl1.1f on a woodpecker board, with dual parallel normally open switches on all of the axes. The configuration is pretty much standard, although I have disabled some of the reporting to make the code fit the Arduino nano.

title: Pxx dwell command values
Wiring a STOP button
body: Is there a way to hardwire a switch to send a STOP command? Thinking of my E-stop button, which has NO AND a NC terminal pair on it. When you close the switch, it opens the circuit (ie: Power in to the drivers) and closes the NO circuit, so my idea is that path is closed and would send the signal to the arduino/GUI to stop sending commands. The power shut off will physically stop the machine. After the switch is flicked back to normal, the GUI could just be in an alarm state and require a set up.

title: How to wire for Stop/Start?
body: Is there a way to hardwire a switch to send a STOP command? Thinking of my E-stop button, which has NO AND a NC terminal pair on it. When you close the switch, it opens the circuit (ie: Power in to the drivers) and closes the NO circuit, so my idea is that path is closed and would send the signal to the arduino/GUI to stop sending commands. The power shut off will physically stop the machine. After the switch is flicked back to normal, the GUI could just be in an alarm state and require a set up.

title: What is the feedrate limit (lowest stepping rate)
body:
I understand that on the high side grbl can pump out about 30khz, What about the lower limit?
I am running into feed rate issue for very a coarse setup. The requirement is to output step pulses
at few 2-10 Hz.. what is the lowest frequency that grbl can pump out reliably? 
Around 30Hz from rough observation, though i would like to know the precise value....

I have a timing belt setup (single axis) with steps per mm at 5.556
Belt is 8mm pitch on a 18 sprocket pulley attached to a nema 34 stepper
the stepper driver is at 800 steps/rev  800/(18X8) = 5.556

$100=5.556
$101=250.000
$102=250.000
>>>>>
$120=15.000
All other settings at default
when i send a jog command
$J=G91 G21 X20 F30.00 N1
the motion completes in under 4 seconds ( should take 40 seconds)
This is about 111 pulses in 40 seconds which is about 2.775 Hz

another jog command
$J=G91 G21 X10 F30.00 N2
completes in under 2 seconds ( should take about 20 sec)

So i give constant distances at different feed rates, till i get
proper time for travel... at about F360 and beyond i start getting
correct duration, this corresponds to about 30Hz as the lower limit

Cheers

title: protocol: add support for optional command checksumming using '*'
body:
While I haven't experienced data corruptions on grbl-based hardware, I have seen scary stuff elsewhere, and I value my fingers/house/machinery.

For extra-paranoid people, the checksumming feature as it's optional is not perfect, as it's still theoretically possible to have the '*' changing to... say... a '2', and the machine would just take a `G0 Z5 *24` as `G0Z5224` instead of `G0Z5`.

title: SPI malfunction when steppers are moving slow
body:
Hello Chamnit, I'm about to finish my GRBL 1.1f port to ATmega644, along with some nice additions (CNC handwheel/dial and analog joystick connection for jogging, realtime SPI transfer of XYZ position data to external 16x2 display, 32 additional I/Os through shift registers connected to SPI, button interface for overrides etc,). Everything works now, thanks to your great efforts in documentation of the source code. BUT: I had to implement a workaround for the classic SPI transfer (write SPDR, poll for SPIF transmission complete flag to be set). When steppers move very slow, SPIF will (randomly) not be set by processor core, although transfer is complete long ago (checked with logic analyzer). So I made up a timeout loop to prevent freezes when polling SPIF. There is absolutely no ISR involved and yes, I set SS port bit DDR to output. I also checked if SPI registers are used anywhere in your code. Nope. This also happens on ramp start/end for faster moves. For testing, I removed all my firmware additions just to test only the SPI issue, SPI tx and SPIF poll loop directly in protocol_main_loop(), just after for(;;) . Still there, it happens even on a plain GRBL. Maybe because of interrupt nesting (sei(); in stepper ISR)? Any idea? For sure I will publish my sources when I'm finished with my project. BTW: is it allowed to pass gc_state.position to mc_line? This eases up my handwheel code: 

gc_state.position[dial_axis] += dial_delta_f; // update selected axis pos.   
mc_line(gc_state.position, pl_data); 
if (sys.state == STATE_IDLE) {  ...
  if (plan_get_current_block() != NULL) { ...
Same applies to my joystick code, where I pass the ADC value to feed override in order to continuously control jog speed after move started by mc_line(): 

loop...
 if (adc_value_has_changed) {
   sys.f_override = adc_value_scaled;
   plan_update_velocity_profile_parameters();
   plan_cycle_reinitialize();
  ...
..until joystick released
Greetings, Carsten

title: Alarm code 2 with positive z move on laser
body:
I got a small laser to play with.  It ran fine straight out of the box with Grbl 9.x that it came with.

I upgraded it with Grbl 1.1f, made the appropriate changes to config.h and installed limit/home switches at both ends of the x & y axis. The limit switches work fine and homing works excellent.

The issue occurs if a positive z move is encountered.  Since Grbl sees the natural machine 0,0,0 as the upper right corner, any attempt to move back, right or up from that corner is seen as out of bounds.

I'm hoping there might be a workaround for this since I'm using the z axis code to trigger the laser on and off.

title: Laser mode - Laser On during jogging
body:
Seems that in Laser Mode, if the Laser was inadvertently left enabled by the g-code, ie in motion mode M4 or if the Spindle speed is left non -zero, the motion algorithm will turn on the laser when the machine is jogged using any of the jog buttons as a result of the movement sensing algorithm.

This is potentially an unsafe situation where the laser could turn on when the user is not expecting it and damage the work or the users eyes.  This also could be a potential hazard when switching back to routing mode if $32 is still set to 1, the spindle could turn on during a jog operation.

Issuing an M5 before jogging is a potential workaround, but the laser/spindle should be automatically disabled during jogging.

title: Limit Switch Trouble
body:
I have an almost functional milling machine running GRBL. The only hurdle to overcome now is that my optical limit switches appear to be triggering on their own. I immediately assumed it was a noise issue, but checking with oscilloscope the signals appear to be good.

![machineoff](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13225720/23258360/d37d53f0-f9bf-11e6-9240-b0860627519a.png)
![machineon](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13225720/23258362/d380f708-f9bf-11e6-9868-04893d67cf33.png)
![postmovement](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13225720/23258361/d3800564-f9bf-11e6-8920-bb7d148a8946.png)
(volts vs milliseconds)

The oscilloscope signals seem to be consistently above 3V or less than 1.5V which correspond to the HIGH and LOW thresholds on Arduino.

My z axis always homes perfectly every time, but my x only works sometimes and y seems to trigger instantly most of the time. In that case the bed (y movement) will not move toward the switch at all, but will instantly jump away from it twice. Is this normal behaviour?

Is there anything else that could be causing issues here? I've configured individual axis homing and the homing per-axis fails in the same way.

I am using [these](https://www.ia.omron.com/product/item/2223/) optical switches. I have the signal wire connected to a 4.7kOhm pullup resistor to 5V.

I didn't record any data when the motors were running as it didn't seem to make a change, however I could go back and get this.

title: Maintain spindle function during homing [[ using spindle PWM signal as charge pump, Gecko G540]]
body:
Hi all,

So I'm looking for a way to maintain spindle function during automated maneuvers such as homing.

I'm using Grbl to control some stepper motors driven by a Gecko G540. The G540 doesn't have a separate enable/disable pin, leaving the motors to whine constantly & build up heat. However, it does have a 'charge pump' that expects a high freq. signal (≥10.5kHz) emitted from the control computer when it's ready to run, allowing it out of a fault mode and delivering power to the motors.

Turns out Grbl's variable spindle PWM output is a sufficiently fast modulation to trick the charge pump into acting like an enable pin. Bookending movements with:
```
m3 s10500    (spindle on @10.5kHz)
g4 p0.2    (brief pre-dwell)
(.....)
g0 x50 f6    (do the g-code stuff)
(.....)
g4 p2    (post-dwell)
m5    (stop spindle)
```
works great for single movements, but when I attempt homing with this arrangement, Grbl automatically disables the spindle while homing, so the G540 driver never exits fault mode & the motors never run.

I tried simply commenting out commands in the c-code that looked like they might be the problem, like  `spindle_stop();` in motion_control.c, but that doesn't seem to make a difference.

I'd expect other stepper drivers also expect a charge pump signal, so perhaps this feature would also have broader use & enable new Grbl applications.  ...for my particular case, I'm just using Grbl to control a set of motors & gantries, so there are not actual spinning cutting tools of destruction to worry about, but minimizing EM noise while the motors idle is important. 

Thanks in advance for the help and code development. This is a really awesome package and I'm psyched about what we'll be able to do with it.

---
_( Also, I realize the spindle speed is in RPM, while the charge pump wants Hz, but the unit-blind conversion value works, so I didn't feel the need to back out the true/effective cutoff )_

title: Simplifying Joystick/Gamepad Control with Jog Feed Override
body:
Hello Chamnit,

Thanks for the great additions in #1.1. 

IMHO it would be great to have a feed rate override also in jog mode. It would make things A LOT easier when using a joystick or gamepad with "analog" XY/ZR sticks.

Given the user moves gamepad stick to the right, do the following:

- issue a realtime jog feed override proportional to current stick angle. 
- jog move cmd to the very end of your machine like "$J=G53X500F2000".
- <loop ...>
-  - get new stick angle
-  - send new jog feed override if changed
- <... until user releases stick to neutral>
- send jog cancel $85.

That's it. You don't have to track the machine position since it would not run above indicated move (X500 in this case). It has no latency in any condition. Only pitfall is: you cannot move in diagonal directions with jog, but I don't need that anyway.

I made minor changes in grbl sources to accomplish this. They need about 120 additional bytes.  

I use ASCII realtime chars 0xF1 to 0xFF (gives 15 different override values from 1 to 200 per cent to select an override value pulled from a loook-up table).  0xF0 may reset jog feed override to 100%.
15 speed steps are totally acceptable as they range from 1% to 200% in an exponential curve. This allows very fine positioning as well as fast moves.

Greetings, Carsten

title: Grbl's character counting protocol
body:
In the description of the Grbl's character counting protocol [https://github.com/grbl/grbl/wiki/Interfacing-with-Grbl](url) is shown an example when sending 25, 40, 31, 58 and 20 characters. The algorithm on the PC side counts the sent bytes and knows which commands stay in the GRBL serial buffer, every GRBL response shows that the top stack command was processed and the space in the serial buffer increased by the number of bytes of this particular command.

Here is my question - if PC see that there is not enough space in the buffer to send the next line but there is still some space available,  is it not worth to send partially the next line and when the response come to send the remaining bytes? I don't understand the point for waiting the buffer to have space for one whole line in order to send it, instead we can fill the serial buffer with part of the new line and send the remaining bytes once the response received.

For example when sending 25, 40, 31, 58 and 20 characters with 127 bytes buffer:
1. We send 25, 40 & 31 - total 96 (remaining 31 characters in buffer)
2. Instead of waiting for response we send 31 characters from next line of 58 characters  - once response received we need to send 27 instead 58 characters.

The advantage of this approach is that the communication throughput will increase and become close to hardware handshaking, the price is slightly more sophisticated processing on PC side.

title: Hardware pin to show serial buffer almost filled
body:
Hi,

When sending multiple GCode small segments to GRBL for moving over a curve in order to get smooth movement the internal serial buffer should be kept semi filled. I agree that by polling the status of the serial buffer &  planner through <?> it's possible to get idea how much space left and to send or hold the next character (on price of more intensive communication).

What about adding one pin to show the serial buffer is almost filled (for example 2-3 bytes left) - this will allow the USB bridge to hold the data transfer to GRBL but still to accept data from PC (if the internal buffers are large). In case the USB bridge buffers become semi filled it's possible to assert the CTS to prevent the PC for further sending the data.

My point is - the SEMI_FILLED pin could be used for developing a proper USB buffer/bridge for GRBL which can hold more data and will allow the users to move smoothly over curved lines without worrying about lost data. This will allow to simple copy the GCode file to serial COM (with hardware hand shacking) and get the whole task done.

title: Reported status (response for <?>) behaviour
body:
When sending the status polling command <?> the GRBL returns the status.

My question is - if I send the <?> command and if the GRBL controller at this particular moment is outputting some data what will happen?

A. The currently active data output will complete and then will execute the <?> to output the status. In this case CR LF at the end of the status data makes sense.

B. The status will be inserted/injected into the currently outputted message (tokens < & > are unique and can be tracked in the outputs). In this case there should be no CR LF at the end of the status data.

From what I see I'm more inclined to think about case A.

Thank you

title: How can my GUI determine how big the serial buffer is on a GRBL implementation?
body:
Grbl 0.9 reported the number of bytes in use in the serial buffer,  0 meant the buffer was empty.  In V1.1 the report changes to "number of serial bytes free".   That makes some tasks of the sender easier.

I'm looking at this issue  [https://github.com/grbl/grbl/wiki/Interfacing-with-Grbl]
  "_When Grbl stores data to EEPROM, the AVR requires all interrupts to be disabled during this write process, including the serial RX ISR. This means that if a g-code or Grbl $ command writes to EEPROM, the data sent during the write may be lost. This is usually rare and typically occurs when streaming a G10 command inappropriately inside a program. For robustness, GUIs should track and detect these EEPROM write commands and handle them appropriately **_by waiting for the queue to finish executing before sending more data_**._"

So I'd like to know if the serial queue is empty.  Previously that was easy.  Is there a way to determine how big the serial buffer is on an implementation so that I can tell when it is empty?  (Indirectly, I guess forcing a processor reset followed by a status query will shows available capacity.  I don't really want to go that route. )  Are there other suggestions or is there a simple way to detect the buffer capacity?

Thanks

The bug is that sending 0x85 to the GRBL sometimes is not aborting the movement. Let me explain in details the circumstances when this occurs. I recorded all data sent to the COM  port (char <…> is the 0x85) when the problem occurred :

G00 X-0.30                            (1)
$J=G90X-558F2000              (2)
…$J=G90X-558Y-2F2000      (3)
…$J=G90X-558F2000            (4)

2. If X+ jog key pressed for longer than 500ms the program sends jog command and instead of sending frequently jog steps I'm targeting the end of the area (x= -558).   At this point the machine begins to move smoothly to the end of X axis (-558).

3. While moving in X direction I can also press the Y- jog key , 0x85 was sent before the command to abort the current jogging movements. This works well, now the head moves simultaneously to end of X and to the beginning of Y axis. 

4. Y- key released , send 0x85 to abort current jogging and send new jog commad targeting end of X axis (x=-558)

5. the X+ jog key released - sending 0x85 to abort the jog operations. The problem appears exactly here - in 2-5% of the cases the machine just ignores 0x85 command and continues to move. 

Let me know if you find something incorrect in my jog commands which may cause the problem.

In short - sometimes 0x85 command is not aborting the currently executed jog movements.

Best regards,

title: Question: Tool Number
Improving Jog command
body:
The existing in v1.1 jog functionality works well but it's possible to simplify significantly the support of jogging from the main program by adding one small feature.

At the moment the jogging works in the following way (a simplified example for moving on X axis when pressing X+ button for longer than 500ms):
1. The program sends several commands $J=G91 X1.0 F1000 to keep the buffer semi filled    (relative move of the head on 1mm with feed rate 1000mm/min )
2. When the X+ button was depressed the program sends immediately CMD_JOG_CANCEL  (code 0x85) which aborts the movement and also clears the buffer (history)

Notice that the program should feed all the time the GRBL buffer with new jog commands.

One other approach is to send a single command for jog movement to some far away point instead of multiple small segmented movements and abort the movement when jog ended. For example when pressing X+ button longer than 500ms we could send 
1.  $J=X600.0 F1000  (X600 is the end of the working area of the machine). The head will keep moving against the far end of the working area with the desired feed rate and there is no need for sending new jog commands.
2. When X+ button depressed we send CMD_JOG_CANCEL  (code 0x85) which aborts the movement immediately

When we go in opposite direction (X- button pressed for more than 500ms)  we can send  $J=X0 F1000 in similar way.

This approach works well (if not desired accelerating jogging speed) but there is one place where it's not perfect - if while moving in X+ direction the user presses Y+ button (by still keeping pressed the X+ button) the head should stop first with CMD_JOG_CANCEL  and then to start moving to the new target. This "hiccup" could be removed by adding a new command - skip current jog operation (CMD_JOG_SKIP) which will force the current movement to complete. If the user sent before the CMD_JOG_SKIP a new jog command the change in the movement will be smooth. For example:

1. User pressed X+ for more than 500ms :
 - send  $J=X600.0 F1000

2. User presses Y+ while X+ still pressed:
  - send  $J=X600.0 Y400 F1000
  - send CMD_JOG_SKIP  which will skip the currently executed jog command and force the GRBL to start executing the new $J=X600.0 Y400 F1000 ASAP
 
3. And of course when both keys were depressed - send CMD_JOG_CANCEL  

So the request is for adding a new command to force the completion of the currently executed jog command.

BTW one question - when sending cancel command (CMD_JOG_CANCEL) does the movement abort immediately (just stop moving the head) or it uses the deceleration profile for the steppers (which prevents losing of steps)? 

Thank you

title: Grbl state during G4
body:
Grbl reports "Idle" during a G4 pause command. There are several reasons why I personally believe this is wrong, but the primary one is safety. 

A user that sees an idle state might think that the controller is really idle, which it is not in reality, and if commands from whatever GUI are slated to be sent, the machine could suddenly start moving unexpectedly.

Another reason I feel this is wrong is because even though a G4 is not a motion command, it is still a valid part of a G-code program. Other controllers enter a Run state and don't exit that state until an program end command such as M02 is encountered.  I understand that GRBL operates differently since it operates on a single line at a time, but if a line is being operated on, even if it is a non-motion line, shouldn't Grbl show "Run"?

title: WIKI note error
body:
This is just a minuscule issue.  On the main WIKI page it states that there two deviations from written g-code standard with one noted as follows.:

G0 and G1 are accepted with no axis words to set the motion mode and feed rate. Common on industrial machines. 

This is not technically correct. G0 and G1 in Grbl respond exactly as they do in LinuxCNC. In linuxCNC all axis words are optional in both G0 and G1. G0 can always be used by itself, and G1 only needs a defined feed rate. If a feed rate has already been defined in a previous line then G1 can be on a line by itself. In this sense I see no difference in the operation of G0 or G1 in Grbl versus LinuxCNC, or many other controls.

Am I missing something?

title: Probe cycle problems
body:
I am writing some automated probing cycles for my GUI and have come up against a problem.  I am not sure if this is a GUI or a Grbl problem, but I believe it is Grbl.  The probe cycle I am implementing is a corner probe cycle where it goes through the many steps. Below is an example of a few lines where the problem occurs, with the grbl echoes shown in bold. I have added a description of what the code is doing with each issued command.

==== START Z ====
**[echo: G91G38.2Z-0.3F1]** (Probe Z- (faster feed rate))
**[PRB:-3.0000,-3.0000,-3.0375:1]**
**ok
[echo: G91G0Z0.100]** (rapid Z+ for pull off)
**ok
[echo: G91G38.2Z-0.2F1]** (probe Z- (slower feed rate)
**[PRB:-3.0000,-3.0000,-2.9454:1]
ok
[echo: G91G0Z0.100]** (rapid Z+ for pull off)
**ok**
==== Z Done ====
==== START X ====
**[echo: G91G0X-0.3]** (rapid -X to get off corner)
**ok
[echo: G91G0Z-0.2]** (rapid Z- to position probe below top of part)
**ok
[echo: G91G38.2X0.3F1]** (probe X+ (faster feed rate))
**[PRB:-3.2879,-3.0000,-3.0468:1]
ok
[echo: G91G0X-0.100]** (rapid X- for pull off)
**ok
[echo: G91G38.2X0.2F1]** (probe X+ (Slower feed rate))
**[PRB:-3.3772,-3.0000,-3.0468:1]
ok
[echo: G91G0X-0.100]** (rapid X- for pull off)
**ok**
==== X Done ====
==== START Y ====
**[echo: G91G0Z0.2]** (rapid Z+ above part)
**ok
[echo: G90G53G0X-3]** (rapid X to where X started from)
**ok
[echo: G91G0Y-0.3]** (rapid -Y to get off corner)
**ok
[echo: G91G0Z-0.2]** (rapid Z- to position probe below top of part)
**ok
[echo: G91G38.2Y0.3F1]** (probe Y+ (faster feed rate))

There are more steps after this, but this is an example of where a problem is occurring.  As you can see, Grbl echoed the G91G38.2Y0.3F1 line properly, but never starts movement on this command. Also, there is never a probe response sent or an "ok" message, or Alarm, or error. When this happens, my GUI is waiting for a probe result. The problem doesn't always occur at this specific spot, but it always happens at the issuance of a G38.2 command. Sometimes it gets all the way through the whole subroutine successfully. At the point or failure, the GUI is still receiving status responses, and they show that Grbl is Idle. Here is a cut and paste of one. 

<Idle|MPos:-3.4142,-3.0000,-3.0468|FS:0.0,0|Ov:100,100,100>

While in this state, non-realtime commands don't work, but I can send a reset an it resets, but something is going on.

Let me know what you think.

title: Need some help with project "Multiaxis Stepping Coprocessor"
body:
@chamnit 
#46 is part of it. And I got some good hints from You. Would You like to discuss a little?

The idea is to make a cnc controller board a simple coprocessor executing steps. It gets prepared line segments over a simple binary protocol and executes them. Primary target is existing hardware with old and slow AVR processors. Think of having grbl main code running on raspberry pi (or something else) sending line segments to something which does the timer ISR. (Yes, there is a lot of trouble with peripherals like endstops etc. - Just let me try :-) )

Currently implemented is a communication protocol over serial and 8-Bit bresenham, doing more than 70000 steps/s on six axis - all at full speed. With some timing delays for stepper drivers (1-2 us) and running serial communication it is still more than 60000 (on 16 MHz 328p). That looks promising.

One open item is step timing. Ranade does not work well as I understand. Maybe linear timer advance per line segment could to the job.
Another problem is a bit tricky: how to initialize the bresenham error value on each line segment? Than means: Should I position slow axis pulses at be beginning, the middle or the end? Make it random? Or track an initial value on host and send it?
(Random is interesting. It distributes aliasing effects over a wider spectrum. Did anyone try that?) 
AMASS is good - but "fine tuning". Or would it help me with bresenham issue?
Homing and probing is a bigger problem. The host processor is not realtime.

I can try all those things.

What I'm asking You:
What is You general opinion about this idea?
Do You have some hints how to generate those stepping line segments in grbl? They have to be shorter than 128 steps but not too short at high speeds (limit is about 500-1000 segments/s). 

It is not important to have my "experiments" in grbl main project. And 'im not asking You to make any changes. Just give me a bit of Your experience! :-)

title: Step by Step acceleration in a CPU-friendly way
body:
@chamnit :Hello,
There is an interesting paper on the net:
[http://www.embedded.com/design/prototyping-and-development/4008259/Linear-motor-control-without-the-math](http://www.embedded.com/design/prototyping-and-development/4008259/Linear-motor-control-without-the-mathl)
I could implement it a way which allows running on 8-bit cpus. Really amazing: No float calculations, not division, no multiplication and no table lookups required in stepper interrupt. Just some adding and shifting - all 16bit.
Biggest advantage is saving a lot of cpu time: There are only 3 line segments needed: accelerate, cruise and deccelerate.
And some disadvantage: stepper interrupt has to run in fixed intervals and not at too high frequency (8-16 khz). Not a big problem: see comments in code.

Now I want to try it in grbl. But I don't want to break too much existing functionality in stepper.c.
Could You take a look at my code and give me some hints how to put that in? 
I think I can do the ISR. But how to calculate the line segments?
You can simply compile main.c on PC and play with it.

[steptimer.zip](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/files/627957/steptimer.zip)

title: problem with classic mode
Problem with Pause->Stop behaviour
body:
I am working on improvements of LaserWeb3 especially for the new Grbl features and have some trouble with hold and reset (in combination with character counting protocol):

- For pause, we use '!' hold command to get immediate response, which works well with new grbl (but will be a problem if used with older grbl, as the laser will not be switched of!).
- Resume with '~' is also ok. 
- On stop we send '0x18' (ctrl-x) which works well while the job is running, but if the job was paused before, grbl remains in hold state an doesn't clear the queue.

@chamnit : Do you have any suggestion how to solve this issue?

title: Timer1 prescaler
body:
@chamnit Sonny, could you briefly explain where the Timer1 is being started in stepper.c in (default) case of using AMASS ?

I can only see  `TCCR1B = (TCCR1B & ~((1<<CS12) | (1<<CS11))) | (1<<CS10); // Reset clock to no prescaling.` but according to the ATmega datasheet (pg 173) this STOPS the Timer1

I can also see `TCCR1B = (TCCR1B & ~(0x07<<CS10)) | (st.exec_segment->prescaler<<CS10);` but that is only for the case with no AMASS...

Thanks!

title: Laser mode tweaks.
body:
ALL: Here are a list of tweaks I'm working on implementing prior to v1.1 master release! Please comment on them, if you disagree, have concerns, or think it's not the right thing to do for ANY reason. I'm fairly new to laser cutters and need user help to figure out some of the details.

- The laser will be automatically disabled whenever the motion mode is not G1, G2, or G3. This includes G0, G38.x, and G80 gcode commands. This is for safety reasons. I just got into laser cutters and it's very evident that safety is a huge issue with these devices. Fires are very easy to start.

- @DOUG888: In response to your earlier query. https://github.com/grbl/grbl/issues/1129  After much thought, I'm going to add laser disabling during a feed hold as the standard behavior.

- There will be two distinct laser cutting modes. Constant power and Dynamic power (acceleration ramp adjusted). They will be controlled by an M3 and M4 command, respectively. You would normally use M3 constant power mode, but in special cases, like finer detail jobs, M4 dynamic power mode can be used.
  - NOTE: The spindle direction pin will still behave the same way with M3 and M4. So it can be used with an LED to indicate which mode is active.

title: 1.1d (20161311) : Change unit and then send '?'
body:
@chamnit
I congratulate you on your work to come up with Grbl-1.1.
Many improvements since version 0.7 (2012)!

Issue:
After the start-up and a first command '?' the report contains 'WCO' which can be stored in 'lastWCO'.
But after a change of unit, the first command '?' the report does not (usually) contain 'WCO'.
The calculation 'workPos = Mpos - lastWCO' becomes false because 'Mpos' uses one unit (eg mm) and 'lastWCO' uses another one (inches).
Does the GUI have to make the correction or Grbl could systematically send 'WCO' after a change of unit?

What is your opinion ?

******* Traduct ty Google *****************

This cnc is for a mate of mine who really wants to cut stuff and is not got enough time to be fluffing around with wiring etc so he gets me to do it, likewise I don't want him using something unreliable as it will inevitably soak up more of my time, so GRBL has been a good choice, simple and so far very effective. Cheers fellas!

title: Dsicussion, new feature: Spindle Coolant Temp monitoring with possible alarm
body:
It appears that there is a trend towards running micro cnc machines with water cooled cnc spindles. For water cooled spindles, having a good flow, and good cooling is critical to the life of the spindle. 

Having the ability for grbl to monitor a temperature probe that is inside the cooling loop could provide extremely valuable information as to the health of the system. Additionally, being able to trigger alarms based on thresholds for nominal coolant temp that could be used to shut the machine down, or put everything in sleep mode could save expensive repairs if something was to fail in the cooling loop.

Marlin 3D printer Firmware was orignally forked from grbl, and has temp probe monitoring. I would think that could serve as a strong base for implementation; though not positive the full array of temp sensors would need to be supported in grbl. 

This is the particular device I have in my cooling loop
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CMR3CC2

Thoughts?

title: Comment Mistake and added PWM speed
Where Headed?
body:
@chamnit :  Just a few questions regarding where GRBL is heading if you can answer. These would obviously be questions regarding the ARM version as the UNO is maxed out.
1. Backlash Compensation - Sounds like it is already already planned
2. Canned cycles - Although mine and a few other GUI's have incorporated some of the canned cycles, is there any plan to incorporate them natively into GRBL?
3. Cutter radius compensation.  This is a feature that I think is preventing a good number of people from implementing GRBL on metal cutting milling machines. I have looked at implementing this in a GUI, but it is problematic since it requires look-ahead, look behind,  position tracking, mode tracking,(G90/G91), etc. Much of the work would be re-creating much of what GRBL already has to do.  This one is definitely not trivial even in grbl.  Just wondering if it is even on the horizon? 
4. Spindle synchronization -  I remember you mentioning you have a CNC'd lathe, so you would know how important this feature is to lathe operations in particular. In my opinion, without spindle sync GRBL is not an adequate option for lathes. I love GRBL and am a definite convert, and would love to see this so I can use it with my lathe. Are there any future plans to implement this?

I know there are likely many other things planned and that the above list is specific to metal cutting. I am a metal head and these are the ones that interest me the most, but I fully understand that there are many other users that are not using GRBL on metal cutting lathes and mills, and they have interests as well, and the above list might not do anything for them.  I'm just wondering at this point.

Thanks,

John B.

title: Some general discussion about programming language and coding style
body:
This is a bit off topic but might be useful when starting a version 2.0 in far future.
I'm not really fan of plain c programming. But on controllers it is ok. Especially with that clean coding style we find in grbl.
I thing using C++ in Arduino style is absolutely a no-go. Performance and flexibility of most libraries ist simply :-1: 
But recently I discovered C++ templates for controller programming. They are basically "macros on steroids".
You can keep all code in headers and instantiate it in a single main.cpp. 
That makes less files, less hassle with declarations and less global variables.
GCC (AVR-GCC too) can do amazing optimizations on that kind of code. Nearly all small functions and all those called from only one place get inlined and globally optimized. I'm often surprized by very small binary output.
Biggest problem with C++ is not language but programmers. C++ programmers tend to make code overly abstract and and complicated - just because the language allows that.

title: Scale spindle PWM (Laser power) by acceleration?
body:
What i want is scale Laser power down while accelerating / deccelarating. I think this would solve the problem of deeply burned edges and other small figures.
It can be easily done in st_prep_buffer().
Formula would be: new PWM = calculated PWM \* [current_speed from acceleration code] / reference speed. (simple version, there should be a configurable minimum)
What would be the best value for "reference speed"?
I suppose the output of plan_compute_profile_nominal_speed() would be OK, but I'm not sure.

If VARIABLE_SPINDLE definition is commented the make is failed with this error:
**gcode.c: In function 'gc_execute_line'**
**gcode.c:1102:9: too many arguments to function 'spindle_set_state' spindle_set_state(SPINDLE_DISABLE,0.0);**

In code definition  **spindle_set_state** is

```
#ifdef VARIABLE_SPINDLE
  void spindle_set_state(uint8_t state, float rpm)
#else
  void spindle_set_state(uint8_t state)
#endif
```

I attach a zipped patched files
[patch.zip](https://github.com/gnea/grbl/files/541743/patch.zip)

title: How Set Slowly ramp to pwm setpoint?
body: How Set Slowly ramp to pwm setpoint? Most PWM motor controllers will faithfully attempt to instantaneously start or stop a motor, causing massive current inrush.

title: Spindle override on off error in GUI grbl panel
body: When I pause the program and turn the spindle off via the spindle override button it gives me an error. The error reads "Fatal error on write to Grbl, the I/O operation has been aborted because of either a thread exit or an application request"

title: Classic reporting and report GUI mode broken
body:
Just an FYI. `config.h` compile options for classic reporting mode and disabling report GUI mode are broken. I'll likely fix the first and remove the latter. Or maybe remove both. Classic reporting will not fit on 328p Arduinos without removing things like settings strings and such, which at that point, may make it incompatible with most GUIs anyway.

It's highly recommended for GUI devs to use the new Grbl interface standard instead. It'll perform significantly better, contains substantially more real-time data, and is easier to maintain and write for. A lot of these changes were based on direct feedback from multiple GUI developers and some bench performance testing.

title: Modify code CSV format.
body:
- Wrap value in quotes to avoid issue with embedded commas. This occurs
  in one of the alarm codes.

This line was the issue:

```
9,Homing fail,Homing fail. Could not find limit switch within search distances. Try increasing max travel, decreasing pull-off distance, or check wiring.
```
- Change header row format to allow same parsing code as data rows.

This also fixes the github CSV preview renderer, which was including the `(KEY: 1` and trailing `)`.

title: Spindle speed in status reports
body:
Real-time spindle speed seems to have been forgotten in the status reports. It wasn't needed before, but with spindle speed overrides (and lasers), you'll have no idea what the spindle speed Grbl is executing at any particular moment. 

To address this, I'm proposing that we change the realtime "Feed Rate" report field to a "Feed and Speed" field. So from

`F:100.`

to 

`FS:100.,9000`, where `9000` is the spindle RPM with speed overrides.

title: Over ride over applies
body:
original post: https://github.com/winder/Universal-G-Code-Sender/issues/503

Lets say your max speed is 600, and the program is at 500. If I apply +20%, it'll max out. I can still click through, adding up to +100% (1000 total) but the machine will still move 600. The issue is, when you go to lower the value there is no real world speed effect until you are again at 20% or lower (so 8-80 clicks of no effect and potential damage). Not sure how you can limit this, but it's something that should be done. Cheers
